Ottawa,
April 22, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a memorandum from the Director of the Surveys and Engineering Branch of this Department in which he states that the work at the Crowfoot Residential School is now completed with the exception of some interior painting and decorating. He states that the contractor has agreed to do this work for $90.00. I am informing Mr. Wardle that he may arrange for having this work completed. You will likely receive instructions from the supervising engineer in regard to it.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hosey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

G. H. Gooderham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Gleichen, Alta.
Ottawa,
April 22, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 16th instant enclosing quotation which you have received for storm windows, screens and door for the recently completed addition to the Crowfoot Residential School.

No provision was made in our current year's appropriation for such a large amount for the purpose mentioned in your letter.

It should be possible for the school staff and the older boys to make screen windows and storm windows at comparatively little cost. A report just received from another Residential School this morning contained the information that the boys, under the direction of a member of the staff, had made some 50 screen windows at a minimum of expense.

If the Principal is prepared to carry out the suggestion made in this letter the Department would consider supplying the material that would be necessary. In this event detailed information should be supplied in order that purchase can be made by our Purchasing Branch.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

G. H. Gooderham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Cleichen, Alta.
Ottawa,
April 28, 1936.

Memorandum:

MR. WARDLE

Re: Addition to Crowfoot Residential School, Cluny, Alberta.

I note from your memorandum of April 14 that the above building has now been completed with the exception of the interior painting and decorating.

I also note that you can have the painting and decorating completed at a cost of $90.00 which amount you consider is reasonable. I would, therefore, appreciate if you would instruct your supervising engineer to give our Indian Agent all details in regard to the incompleted work. Payment of the amount of $90.00 will be made on receipt of accounts.

[Signature]

Director.
April 30th 1938

Blackfoot Indian Agency,
Gleichen, Alta.

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith the following report for the month of April 1938.

Visits were made at both schools and pupils all seemed to be in reasonably good health. The Crowfoot addition is practically finished but the class rooms will not be occupied this term. During the holidays, desks, book closets and equipment must be moved and plumbing main taken from the building to the basement of the annex. Farm work and land cultivation was well in hand.

Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

Re - Addition to Crowfoot Residential School, Blackfoot Indian Reserve, Cluny, Alberta.

Our Chief Engineer advises that the inside painting work on the above building has been completed by contractor Holmes for the sum of $90.00 as agreed upon. Mr. Goderham, your Indian Agent, has certified that such inside painting and decorating work has been completed in accordance with specifications.

As you know, this contract was formally closed out at the end of the fiscal year to permit payments being made, the understanding being that your Branch would pay the $90.00 painting bill referred to. It will now be in order to pay this account as soon as it is received by you from the contractor.

This building has been formally turned over to your Indian Agent and the contractor has been released from carrying any further fire insurance on it.

We will forward you a complete set of photographs of the new building in the near future.

Director.

Attention Schools Branch.

Dear Sir:

The addition to the Crowfoot Residential School is complete except for storm windows and plumbing which the Principal wants installed and moved from the main building. There is also a request that certain plumbing changes be made in the main building.

The Local Plumber was asked to submit a quotation on this work. To install two baths, four basins, four closet combinations, one urinal trough 4' with flush pipe, one apron sink 42" cast (in dairy), build one partition and taking up floors and repairing same in the addition, moving bath and supplying new closet combination for Sisters' bath room adjacent to the room they propose to use for a dormitory and doing all repairing and supplying all necessary fittings, he asks the sum of $354.00.

To make the necessary changes in the dormitories as the removal of a wall, making a door and putting a partition in the Sisters' dormitory, it is estimated that the cost will exceed $200.00.

The total cost of the changes, including the plumbing will then be in the neighbourhood of $600.00 and this does not include the storm windows for the addition. The plumbing changes are necessary and so is most of the work if this school with its new addition is to overcome the overcrowded condition. Please instruct us in this as the work should be done during the summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
EX'D.

Ottawa,
June 7, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 1st instant with reference to the Crowfoot Residential School.

In our current year's appropriation the amount of $750.00 was provided for repairs, improvements and new equipment at this school. We have already expended $22.90 for rebuilding the chimney and $90.00 for painting, or a total of $112.90. This leaves a balance of $637.10 and it will, therefore, be possible to favourably consider the recommendations made by you in the second and third paragraphs of your recent letter.

However, before authorizing you to proceed with the work I would appreciate your advising the name and address of the "local plumber" from whom you have obtained a quotation. I presume that his quotation of $384.00 includes both material and labour.

In connection with the changes to the dormitories I think you mentioned this when you were in the Department last winter and I am under the impression that your estimate of $200.00 refers to material only. In that event, or even in the event of the material costing more than $50.00, it will be necessary for you to supply full particulars regarding what is required in order that purchase may be made through our Purchasing Branch.

Yours truly,

C. H. Gooderham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Glenchen, Alta.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
June 8, 1938.

Referring to your letter of the 1st instant and my reply of the 7th instant I was talking to one of the engineers from the Surveys & Engineering Branch this morning and he felt that if at all possible it would be advisable to secure quotations for the work required at the Crowfoot Residential School from two or three qualified parties. No doubt you will endeavour to do this before replying to my letter of yesterday's date.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill,

Re - Addition to Crowfoot Indian Residential School.

I have your memorandum of June 7th quoting a letter received by your Indian Agent, Mr. Gooderham, from Mr. H. Holmes, the Contractor.

I might say that it is our practice to request the Finance Department to return the security deposit just as soon as a contract is completed but there seems to be always some routine delay in this matter. However, on June 7th a cheque for $1,310.85 was forwarded to Mr. Holmes, being a refund of his deposit plus accrued interest. There was a little delay in this matter because Mr. Holmes' security deposit had been sent in by the Crown Lumber Company, Limited.

Director.

Ottawa, July 7, 1928.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer you to my letter of the 7th ultimo, with reference to the Crowfoot Indian Residential School. I would appreciate very much receiving an early reply to that letter, giving the information requested.

My letter of June 7th stated that there was a balance of $657.10 available. Recently, we received an account for $14.35. Payment of this latter account means that there is now only an amount of $622.75 available.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

G. H. Gooderham, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Glenchen, Alberta.
WORKS PROGRAMME AT CROWFOOT SCHOOL

In Old (Main) Building:

1. Girls playroom to be turned to a sewing room & cloak room with a partition 25'x14' and door.

2. Boys' playroom to be changed to kindergarten class room and cloak room. Partitions 25x14 and door.

3. Junior class room to be Sisters' dormitory, visitors bedroom and a cloak room. Partitions 28½x14 & 14x20 and two doors.

4. Boys' (basement) lavatory and bath room to be 4 storerooms for vegetable, fruit and trunks etc. One partition 28½x10 and one door. Shelving for fruit 2 walls 24½ each.

5. Move bath toilet and partition from West end to small room adjoining Sisters' (new) dormitory.

6. Move 12 long wall closets to new locations and also build 2 new ones 10x12 and 10x23 in new cloak rooms.

7. Rear verandah (rotten) on first floor must be rebuilt. New flooring 95x9 required. This is much used and important.

§. IN NEW ADDITION:

1. Toilet, bathroom and dairy in basement - new partition 8 x 23 and door; moving from main building 2 baths, 3 toilets 4 wash basins with partitions and setting up. Dairy already equipped with 2 motors, drain boards etc. - a splendid dairy and the Department did not buy any new equipment for it.

2. Principal is installing a drinking fountain on main floor also in Indian waiting room of Main building at no expense to the Department.
The action of the Principal is something new but is refreshing. We have gone over the programme of work and consider every move is either very necessary or a decided improvement over the existing layout. In fact, the new addition is of little value unless these changes are made nor will the overcrowding in the main building be eliminated without them. Needless to say, it is the least costly method and we are satisfied that the Principal and his assistants are quite capable of doing all the work set out on the list.

An early reply is requested as the work should proceed through the holiday period.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Gleichen, Alta.
July 7, 1938.

Attention Mr Phelan - Schools Division

RE: Crowfoot Residential School - Blackfoot Res.

Dear Sir:

Upon receipt of yours of June 7th file 1004-2-5 I got in touch with the Acting Principal of the school, Revd. Father Lessard. When it was known that only $637.10 was now available for repairs etc., it was quite evident that all could not be done that should be done unless labour costs were reduced materially. So Father Lessard got busy and worked out a programme of work using cheap labour and I think you will agree that he will do more with this allowance than we've ever done in the past, if the scheme is authorized.

In the first place, he would eliminate all high-priced mechanical labour by using a handy man whose wages are $40.00 per month. He then went to the Crown Lumber Co. with a bill of material and ascertained the cost of lumber required. Attached hereto is a list of the work already done or to be done and the Lumber Company's quotation on material. You will note that the Crown Lumber Co submits an net price of $466.00 which leaves $174.00 to pay for everything else. The Revd. Father asks for necessary hardware and paint which he estimates at $75.00 and an allowance of $90.00 to assist in paying for the labour. This will bring the cost to slightly more than the allowance for this school but I trust this may be authorized.

The Crown Lumber Co in Gleichen is the only firm in these parts and is on the Patronage List. Hardware should not exceed $50.00 and can be purchased locally from firms on the list; likewise paint. In regard to the labour, would it be possible to allow the Principal $30.00 per month for the months of June, July & August for a mechanic, by submission of a Voucher through this office as is done in the case of the Night Watchman?

Ottawa, July 14, 1938.

Memorandum:

PURCHASING AGENT:

I enclose purchase order for material required for repairs at the Crowfoot Indian Residential School. The Indian Agent has secured a quotation of $465.02 from the Crown Lumber Company, Gleichen, Alberta. This firm is on the approved list.

The Indian Agent considers that the price mentioned is very reasonable. The school management is prepared to do practically all the work without cost to the Department. The school is now closed for holidays and any repairs should be made within the next few weeks. I therefore recommend that purchase order be issued, authorizing purchase of the articles mentioned on the quotation from the Crown Lumber Company, Gleichen, Alberta, at a cost of $465.02.

Director.
Ottawa, July 15, 1938.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the repairs that you consider necessary at the Crowfoot Indian Residential School.

The tender of the Crown Lumber Company has been submitted to the Purchasing Agent and we have recommended the purchase of the material from them. As soon as we have the decision of the Purchasing Agent, you will be advised.

You may purchase, from firms on the approved list, the necessary hardware and paint, the cost of which is estimated at $75.00. I understand from your letter that two or more accounts will be submitted in connection with these purchases. This method will bring each account under the $50.00 limit.

I am sorry that present regulations will not permit our paying the $90.00 for labour in the manner that you suggest. However, this amount can be expended by keeping paylists. AGENT'S REPORT ON BLACKFOOT AGENCY FOR MONTH OF AUGUST 1938.

Schools

The writer visited both residential schools in connection with repairs and improvements. The children, of course, were still on holidays and did not return until the sixth of July. The improvement and repair work to the Crowfoot school was being carried out with local labor and the acting Principal is to be commended on the class of work and the amount that he was able to do with very limited expenditure. This school was in good shape to properly care for all the pupils this year. The crop at this school was excellent and is now being threshed. At the Old Sun School the staff was concentrating on the harvesting which came off irrigated lands. This land has produced abundance of feed and a good garden as well as some threshed grain. Both schools had done well with their exhibits at the Calgary Fair and prize money was here for the pupils on their return this fall. This coming year more stress will be given to handicraft work and the general work will undoubtedly be more pleasing to the Indian pupils.

Since an addition was made to the main building of this institution there has been a clogging of sewage in the old building at the point where the cold water from an artesian well meets the warm sewage. Extract from Inspector Schmidt's report on the Crowfoot Indian residential school on March 31, 1939:

**CLASS-ROOM EQUIPMENT**

A rearrangement of the classes was made since the two new class rooms were opened; the third room in the main building for beginners and Grade I is not properly equipped with desks and seats. Home-made equipment is used and this is not satisfactory. Eighteen new desks should be supplied. Otherwise, equipment is sufficient for present needs in all three classes. There is room in these class rooms to accommodate more pupils.

(Sgd.) C. P. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Extract from Inspector Schmidt's report on the Crowfoot Indian residential school dated March 31, 1939:

Considerable paint will be required to do the interior of the old building. If this is supplied then the school staff will do the work themselves.

The kitchen range, a very old one, is badly warped; the ovens are burned out and cannot be used. It is not worth repairing. This range was brought to Crowfoot in 1923, from the old Dunbow School, where it had been in use for sometime.

There is no mangel in the laundry; one is badly needed.

The new addition built last year fills a much-needed want; the two class-rooms are large and bright with high ceilings, as is the large boys' playroom in the basement. I am told there are days in winter when the wind is from the North-east, that it is impossible to heat the class-rooms, even though storm-sash have been put on. Apparently the heat cannot be forced through.

I noticed the steampipe in the corridor (basement) between the two buildings, is bare. It might be that if this were covered with hair and asbestos that it might help. I do not understand steam-heating, but am told there is no (return) in this system, and that there should be. I would suggest having someone who understands same check it over.

(Sgd.) C. P. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa,

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a report from Inspector Schmidt with reference to his recent inspection of the Crowfoot Indian residential school. He mentions that considerable painting is required in the interior of the old building and suggests covering the steam pipe in the corridors with asbestos. He also refers to the condition of the kitchen range and the mangle in the laundry.

The amount of $600.00 was provided in the current year's appropriation for repairs, improvements and purchase of new equipment at the Crowfoot school. Of this amount $27.15 was authorized in my letter of the 12th ultimo. The balance is still available and for your information I may say that in view of the present setup of our appropriation it is impossible to exceed the amount specifically provided.

I, therefore, suggest that you confer with the Principal and decide the best manner in which the amount available should be expended. In the event of its being decided to purchase any equipment full details should be given in order that our Purchasing Branch may make the purchase.

Dear Sir:

At the Crowfoot Residential School there is a very large John Bull Range. This is a stove which has two ovens and was brought to this Institution from the Dunbow Boys School at Midnapore, Alberta when this school was dismantled, and it was with considerable difficulty that we got it into the basement at Crowfoot.

For some time it has not been operating very well and certainly requires some repair work. The local people were not in a position to handle it so I got Green's Greater Stove & Repairs Products of Calgary, a concern which does a very great deal of this work throughout the province, to look the stove over and make an estimate of costs.

I am advised that it requires a complete top over one fireplace, one outside section of sectional lid, one grate and grate frame, one ash pan, four oven racks, one damper, tin over one oven and ovens relined with asbestos. This firm quotes a price of $95.00 for the complete job.

The stove is valuable and I hope that it will be possible to authorize this expenditure and put it in good condition.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of yours of the 3rd, file 104-2-5, re a circular letter on fire hazards, and a copy of a letter which you received from the Principal of the Crowfoot Residential School on this reserve.

May I be permitted, first of all, to draw your attention to my letter of November 15th, 1937, when I suggested that something should replace the iron poles as fire escapes, and your subsequent letters, particularly yours of March 3, 1938.

I did require the school authorities to carry on with fire drill and as a result one of the Sisters was badly injured and the Principal refused to proceed with drill after that. I understand he spoke to the Director about conditions of escapes at this school when he visited Ottawa a year ago, on his return from there, and he informed me, on his return here, that Dr. McGill had said it would not be necessary to carry out the full drill. Therefore, as intimated in his letter dated October 28th, there has been no fire drill.

I made an inspection of this school yesterday, and Father Riou and I went about to see what could be done. The poles still stand and access to the poles is over beds and through a window; these take care of the larger pupils. The smaller children, whose dormitories are on the south side of the institution, have easy access to wooden stairs leading down to a back verandah. Aside from the regular inside stairs, these are the only means of escape. We could see no other alternative but to erect iron fire escapes at the east and west end of the institution, near or where the old escapes now are. The window could be replaced by a fire door. Whether the Department would be in a position to go to this expense, I don't, of course, know. I can say one thing, however, that the Staff of this institution is now fire conscious. The night watchman is an active young man and I think he will keep the fire apparatus in good condition.

I have no other remarks to make.

Your obedient servant,

C. H. Gooderham, Indian Agent.

AGENT'S REPORT ON BLACKFOOT AGENCY FOR MONTH OF APRIL.

Both schools were inspected and pupils were found to be in reasonably good health and cheerful—especially so at the Crowfoot school. Some changes should be made at the Old Sun School in the staff; the nurse is not efficient, nor is one of the Matrons. The principal also advises me that he proposes to strengthen his teaching staff by putting a more capable teacher in the junior room. In this I entirely agree, as it is this room that the real ground work is done. One member of the staff, Mr. Bell, the farmer, has enlisted. He has been replaced by Mr. Toone, who has been at this school for some time and will carry on very well, I believe. Mr. Bell was an especially good farmer and brought the farm and the dairy herd to the highest point of efficiency and productivity in the history of this institution.

At the Crowfoot school the spring run-off cut a deep canal right through the middle of their farm, at the rear of the institution. This canal has been in existence for some years in draining off the water from north of the town of Cluny and the artesian wells in the town. The existing canal is dangerous and something must be done to prevent further erosion and it is now our duty to find out with whom the responsibility of fixing this rests.

At both institutions everything is ready to go ahead with seeding when conditions will allow.

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Re: Crowfoot Indian School

On a recent inspection of this school it was brought to my attention that there is only one good sewing machine in the institution and this cannot handle all the necessary work to be done; there is no machine for the Sister in charge of the boys with which she can repair their clothing. What is really required is a tailor's, motor driven sewing machine. This will cost considerable more than an ordinary foot-driven machine and if the motor cannot be supplied, this school should be supplied with a foot-power tailor's sewing machine.

At this same time, the hot water heating coils in the large kitchen range burst and I had to get a plumber to shut off the water. Fortunately, the stove has two fireboxes and, at the present time when there are no pupils at the school, the stove can be used but no water is being heated. The new coils must be brought from Winnipeg with the linings, which are beyond repair. This is an old stove which was bought by the Principal many years ago from Dumbol School, when that institution was closed. Although these repairs will cost considerable, it is a very small charge compared to a replacement. At the moment it is not known just what these repairs will cost.

RE: REPAIRS CROWFOOT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Dear Sir:

Further to my letter of the 19th instant, re heating system at the Crowfoot Res. School, we have found that it is in very bad condition and that considerable repairs & replacements will be necessary before this institution can get hot water or fire the heating boiler. To date, I have only received requirements & estimated costs for the hot water plant; the repairs to the heating plant will include the services of a steam fitter, a brick mason & a welder. I have asked the steam fitter, Mr Michael, to get these men to give him an estimate of the cost of material & labour and then submit the total estimated cost. This plant has been in operation since 1912.

Mr Michael spent some time going over the plant and found the hot water boiler half full of sediment so he cleaned it out. The jacket heater was also in very bad condition; the bottom fell out of it and it must be replaced by a new heater large enough to heat a tank of 380 gallons capacity. He has submitted the attached estimate to cover the cost of replacement - it appears to be reasonable and as good, if not better, than any other quotation we might get, I think, as there is no other plumber or steam-fitter nearer than Calgary.

Authority for this expenditure is required as early as possible, please.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge yours of the 27th inst. authorizing an expenditure of $138.00 for the hot water boiler at the Crowfoot Res. School.

I have now received an estimate for the repairs to the heating boiler; it is higher than anticipated. Attached is an estimate from L. Michael, one from the welder D. MacDonald, and one from the Crown Lumber Co for material. The bricklayer J. Davenport states that the labour costs of re-bricking will not exceed $50.00; he says that it will take him and a helper almost a week, his rate of pay is therefore very reasonable. All these mechanics are the best in their line in the district.

With regards to brick, the bricklayer wants all new bricks but Mr. Michael contends that salvaged bricks could be used on the North wall because it is only a fire travel - this would reduce the purchase of new bricks by 500 and the amount by $60.00. We find that considerable damage has been done to the brick work and foundation by seepage water. Not only seepage but from water which comes from outside in rainy weather. This keeps the foundation & brick work wet all the year round. Mr. Michael loaned The Principal a small rotary pump with a ¼ h.p. motor attached. This is now in the boiler room and pumps water from the ash-pit. It is slow but it does the work. A large automatic sump pump installed will cost about $125.00 but if funds are not available, I would seriously recommend the purchase of the one loaned by Mr. Michael. He will accept $30.00 for the outfit. The pump is new and I know the price is right.

The water front for the range arrived today and is being installed, the cost is $30.00. I have instructed Mr. Michael to install a new hot water boiler. I shall await your instructions about the heating plant.

Dear Sir:

It was reported to this office on the 25th instant that the large pressure tank which supplies water throughout the Crowfoot Residential School and its new addition had burst. This tank has a diameter of five feet and is 24 feet long; it is buried in the ground at the east end of the school with its west end through the foundation into what is known as the Tank Room in the basement of the school. It has remained in this position since 1912. In 1938 an annex was added to the school and the east end of the tank leads in through the foundation into the west end of the basement of the annex. I am submitting a small rough sketch which I have made and which may be of value in helping you to picture this situation. This is the unit which supplies all the water for this school and is, therefore, all important, for without it there is no water in the pipe lines and no real fire protection.

I instructed Steam Fitter Michael of Gleichen to investigate and report on this case. He found that the west end was blown from a concave to a convex condition and that the water glass was broken and where this end was riveted it had been loosened to such an extent that it was no longer air tight. He believed, however, that it might be electric welded and considered this was worth trying before considering a replacement or an auxiliary system. I instructed him to take Electric Welder McDonald of Gleichen and attempt this. On the 28th instant he reported that the welder had worked for some hours and failed to make an air tight job although it was possible to pump air into the tank and give pressure for a limited amount of water, but as the air continuously escapes the automatic cut-out works very frequently. This automatic cut-out, by the way, was ordered only one week before the tank burst and had not yet been installed.

In company with McDonald, Michael and a representative of Metals Limited, I inspected the plant at the school and thoroughly discussed the situation as it now existed. I have also since consulted the head of one of the best welding concerns in Calgary and am now prepared to make certain recommendations.

I recommend that two 30" x 72" tanks be installed in one end of the tank room and connected up with the water system. These tanks are the largest size that can be brought through existing windows in the foundation and their combined capacity-

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.
capacity is 370 gallons. The tank room is small and there is but room for these two at one end of the room near enough to the existing connections to require very little extra piping. It will be necessary, however, to carry a line of half-inch pipe around the corridors to the annex in order to supply water for the boys' toilets and the dairy room. Mr. Michael and Metals Limited have quoted, for the tanks and installation, a price of £237.00. With an automatic cut-out and careful use of water these tanks will supply the needs of the school for months, if necessary.

This recommendation is made because it is believed that the large tank may still be in good condition. The outside has been protected from weather and is as good as new; the inside, however, can only be inspected by cutting out one end and cleaning it. The procedure recommended for this would be to cut the rivets from the west end and remove it, wash and clean the inside and examine for pits. If found in good condition, the end would be taken to some reliable welding concern in Calgary and either strengthened or replaced and electric welded into position about six inches in from the present head. If, of course, a new tank is needed such would have to be built to order and considering what size could be placed in the location of the existing tank, unless some other location was found to be more practical and applicable. After the large tank was repaired or replaced the two auxiliary tanks could be used elsewhere.

Delivery and installation of these small tanks can be made immediately. At the moment there is only the Staff living in the institution and it is not advisable to bring pupils in until there is a proper water system operating.

Please instruct by Air Mail or wire.

Dear Sir:

Herewith my report for the month of September 1941.

SCHOOLS:

Schools did not open until the 22nd and the writer did not make an inspection after that date. Pupils were apparently happy to return but the parents have been very slow in bringing in children who were entering for the first time. As usual, there was the unfortunate situation where there were mixed marriages and many disputes as to which school the child should attend. Our only interest is that the child of school age should go to school and we do not consider it our duty to either advise or dictate to the parent where the child must be placed. Very little vocational work has been started at either school as accommodation has not yet been provided. A temporary plant to supply necessary water at Crowfoot School has been set up. From a recent survey and information given to me, I am glad to report that the children returned to school generally in very good physical condition. The T.B. Clinic will commence almost immediately, when the real condition will be known.

Dear Sir:

The Provincial Boiler Inspector reported that the upright heating boiler at the Crowfoot Indian School needed certain repairs including safety valves and some re-tubing. The local plumber was sent to do this work and he repaired the safety valves, but when he started on the tubes he found so many were burnt and leaking that he discontinued this work and reported that in his opinion it should all be retubed as it had to be moved off its base and turned on its side to do any retubing.

The Boiler Inspector was here again yesterday and he confirmed Mr. Michael's report.

I have today received from Mr. Michael an offer to retube this boiler at a cost of $135.00, subject of course to the securing of tubes, which are, at present, available in Calgary.

This boiler is used in heating water for the laundry at this institution and has had nothing done to it in 18 years. Though antiquated, it does the job alright and I would like to be instructed as to whether Mr. Michael should proceed with this work. It can be operated temporarily but must be repaired within the present fiscal year.

Calgary, May 26th, 1948

Sir:

Reference Departmental letter No. 104-2-5 of the 27th ultimo, re repairs to the roof of the Crowfoot Indian Residential School, I beg to report that I discussed this matter with Mr. G. H. Gooderham, the Indian Agent, and Rev. F. Forestier, the Principal.

In looking over the roof, which has a dome; also the cornices and eaves-troughing, all of which need to be repaired, it was decided that a qualified and competent tradesman be employed to check same over carefully, and take charge of the work. I suggested to Agent Gooderham that he ask our Department to approach the Department of Public Works and ask that an engineer or architect from the Banff, Alberta, staff be instructed to do this. I mentioned Mr. Snelson, who supervised the construction of the class-room annex at this (Crowfoot) School in 1938, and who also took charge of and supervised the alterations and repairs to the Ermineskin School at Hobema, in the same year. If Mr. Snelson's services can be obtained, I believe that the work will be done very economically: this was proven to us last Autumn when the matter of installing a new pumping unit at the Blood Agency was being looked into, and the work done under Mr. Snelson's guidance, cost less than one-half of the estimate submitted by a firm in Cardston. (Reference Dept. No. 21-103 dated January 21st, 1942).

I am attaching hereto copy of Agent Gooderham's letter to me, and would ask that the matter be taken up with him direct, as my absences from this office are oftentimes the cause of delay in matters of this kind, and it is imperative that the roof, &c., be repaired as soon as possible, to protect the walls and ceilings from rain seeping through.

Your obedient servant,

Michael, Plumber and Tinsmith of Gleichen, and later I understand that Michael was requested to complete a tender for certain definite repairs calling for the re-shingling of the roof, repairs to verandahs and eavestroughing, etc. Mr. Michael states his tender of $961.00 was accepted.

Crowfoot School used a small building for manual training during the fiscal year of 41/42 and it answered the purpose very well indeed. I do not know of any other use that the Principal wishes to make of it; I realize that storage space is limited at this institution and possibly he has in mind using it for this purpose and even using some of the four-roomed house which would be made into a training building for the same purpose. However, under conditions existing these days I am satisfied that the repairs to the vocational building could be left at least until the fiscal year of 43/44. This may break into his plans, but whose plans are not broken into these days? In the first place, material is going to be very hard to get and in the second place I doubt very much if the school will be in a position to supply all the labour. I am, therefore, not going to mention your letter of the 2nd instant to the Principal and unless you so desire, I am prepared to tell him that it is regretted that the money is not available for this work this fiscal year.

Dear Sir:

The pipe system leading from an outside storage tank to the main building at Crowfoot School was leaking so badly that I asked the Principal to put his man to work to uncover it. It was found that the pipeline was eight feet underground and the work entailed was more than this man could cope with so I hired a qualified helper. The pipe, which had been there for 32 years, was found to be badly pitted and leaking in many places. After cribbing, a new pipe was laid and I am pleased to say that water, which has been seeping into this building for some time, has now ceased. At the same time as I was inspecting this work I noted that the safety valves on the pressure tanks were totally inadequate and on learning that they could not be repaired, ordered new ones. I also had the new cooking range set up at this school and the old one torn down and removed. It was hoped that the existing pipe system would be large enough for the new range but it was found that there wasn't sufficient draft, as the pipes were too small. The stove is giving good service but the pipes must be enlarged, necessitating the making of special shaped pipes to travel between the water line and other pipes. The local plumber, L. Michael, could do this work.

The foregoing repairs will cost in the neighborhood of $90.00. While labour was available and as the work was considered urgent, I have had everything done except the enlarging of the stove pipes.

Your obedient servant,

G. H. Gooderham,
Indian Agent.

Mr. G.H. Gooderham, Indian Agent, Gleichen, Alta.

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, enclosing list of material required for the erection of a new piggery at the Crowfoot Indian Residential School.

The contents of your letter have been very carefully considered and it is quite evident that the piggery suggested by the school management would handle a very large number of pigs.

In raising pigs, or other live stock, at a residential school the Department feels that the first matters to be considered should be the provision of food for the pupils and staff and, combined with this, the possibility of training the older pupils at least in the proper manner of raising such stock. We feel that it is inadvisable for Indian residential schools to attempt to raise live stock on a commercial basis. This involves a great deal of work and, while the boys might receive some training, there are so many routine duties requiring attention that the pupils soon develop the feeling that they are simply being worked for the benefit of the school and consequently the value of the training is nearly all lost. Dear Sir:

I make haste to reply to your letter No.104-2-5 dated the 12, and which I received the 16 instant.

For several years at the Duck Lake School, we have been trying to get the senior boys interested in the raising of hogs. And now, over one third of the former pupils of the school raise these animals, not only for their own use but also for the market. This enterprise has not yet met with full success, but we have good reasons to hope that the near future will bring about still better results.

The boys who desire any training in this line have every opportunity of learning all that is required to carry out the work successfully later on. At present from six to eight boys are thus occupied and show great interest in the work.

We have always found it more profitable to raise our own hogs and thereby furnish the school with an ample supply of fresh meat as well as with bacon and ham, which we also teach the pupils to prepare.

From January 1942 to January 1943, we consumed 6,907 lbs of pork and sold for the amount of $1002.97. These figures show the importance of raising hogs, especially during war time.

The shelter which we provide for our pigs is very simple and sanitary at the same time. It has been constructed with material which the Indians may get on their reserves, i.e., logs, slabs, straw, hay and mud and green poles. It consists of two rectangular enclosures one of which is built inside the other at a distance of two feet from the outer one. The dimensions are 80' X 20' for one and consequently 76' X 16' for the other. Each of these two enclosures is built of upright slabs eight feet in length and placed but a few inches apart. Between these two walls we have piled straw mixed with hay. The roof consists of poles overlaid with straw and mud. The interior of the building is divided into five compartments each 15' X 16' X 6', there being a log floor half way across each compartment. Upon this floor is thrown the straw on which the hogs lie. Moreover, each compartment has but one opening which gives access to a pen 16' X 50' also made of upright slabs...and in and out of which the pigs may freely go at all times of the year.
Last fall, our senior boys constructed a log building 30' x 20' upon a concrete foundation two feet high. The walls were plastered with mud both inside and outside. The roof being covered with mud and hay. The structure has four windows and two doors and is divided into six compartments the partitions being made of small poles placed upright and two inches apart. It is in this building that our sows bring forth their litter during the cold months of December, January, February. Out of seventy (70) little pigs born during the winter, we have rescued sixty (60).

The aspect of such structures, not too pleasing to the eye could be improved by keeping the surroundings clean and orderly, and perhaps also by planting trees.

Our modernized buildings may be far more appealing to the stranger than our lowly constructions of slabs and straw. Still I believe that we are making our boy better fitted for the future by training them to work with the different materials and in the same conditions which will be less likely to be handicapped as would happen should they attempt at home to proceed with what their economic conditions would not permit.

Hoping that the above information may prove to be of some value to you, and assuring you of my willingness to co-operate with the Department in its efforts to improve the condition of our Indians,

I am, dear Sir,

Very truly yours,

G.M. Latour, O.M.T.,
Principal.

Dear Sir,

Mr. G.H. Gooderham, our Indian agent has sent me a copy of your letter dated the 13th of this month concerning the new pigery at the Crowfoot Indian Residential School. Before replying to your letter, I did what you suggested, namely, inquired from Father Principal of the Duck Lake School concerning their pigery, of which you also possess information. Upon receipt of the letter from Father Latour, the Principal of the same School, I immediately went to our agent to show him the contents and to discuss the matter. The discussion was brief, because under our present situation, that is, living in the prairie where there is not a single pole or slab available, what has been done at the Duck Lake School is practically out of the question in our location. This I am sure, the Department will be aware of.

The dimension we had given for our new pigery was 66 by 30, and the one in the Duck Lake was 80 by 20, and another 76 by 16, and also another of 30 by 20. You can see that these are much larger than the one we ask for. We would be contented with such a type of pigery if the Department would purchase slabs, posts, and legs, which Mr. Gooderham told me are not available. Last spring we bought some fence posts, 'cedar posts' and as you know, we had to pay 25 cents a piece and we had a very hard time getting them. Transportation amounted to 3 cents a linear foot. I inquired about slabs, and I was told that they are not available around here, that we would have to get them from the mountains west of Banff, and that it would cost us much.

So every angle being considered and our present situation taken into consideration it would cost the Department just as much, if not more to build such a pigery here at the Crowfoot School.

I wish to tell you dear Sir, that if we were in the same kind of country as northern Saskatchewan, where logs, poles, and slabs are plentiful, and this I know by experience, because my home town is Duck Lake, you may believe me; we would do everything we can to show our good will in assisting it in every way.

You seem to infer in your letter, I quote, "From our consideration of the plan suggested by the Principal of the Crowfoot School, we are under the impression that he contemplates raising hogs on a wholesale scale." I wish to point out regarding this, that first, until now we have been providing ourselves with our own meat; secondly, that we are trying our best to train the older pupils in all branches of farm work; thirdly, that we have also to find means to have a certain cash revenue from the farm, for this reason that the School is being paid for 68 pupils and we have 95 in School. We have 23 children for which we receive no assistance from the Department. This cannot be done with the per capita grant we receive.

I am, dear Sir,

Yours truly,

Rev. H. Forester, M.A.,
Principal
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Your File 104-2-5

Piggery Crowfoot Residential School

I have yours of the 24th with enclosures. The Rev. principal of Crowfoot had already shown me a copy of the letter from Father Latour.

Structures such as Duck Lake School has erected are undoubtedly practicable and serviceable and certainly not costly in that part of the country. The Crowfoot school is built on the open prairie where there is no timber, from which to secure the logs. Timber must be obtained from the Rocky Mountains or the foothills.

Logs are very difficult to procure now, and the cost, if transportation must be included, is nearly as much as rough lumber.

I am quite familiar with the straw barn which is used by farmers who can not afford a better building. This is certainly not the type for an institution; it is unsightly, the life of the building is short and great care must be taken to avoid fires.

It is granted that the Indians will not have an elaborate Piggery on their farms but in this part of Western Canada it is just about as cheap to erect a building with lumber and cement as it is to erect one like the one at Duke Lake.

RE: Crowfoot Residential School

I am attaching hereto a copy of a letter received from the Principal of this school, in which he asks for certain laundry, kitchen and dormitory equipment which are badly needed.

The present laundry equipment has been in use thirty years and is beyond repair. It is now a terrible ordeal to do the washing.

This institution was never supplied with a real bread mixer. Some years ago the late principal got a sausage mixer which we rigged up with a small gasoline engine to do the mixing. It was a cheap set up but it served the purpose for a long time.

Previous to that all bread was mixed by hand; this work is far too heavy for growing children.

If the principal takes in new pupils, he must have beds. It is realized how difficult it is to get what is needed but it must be stressed that the need is urgent.

Indian Agent,

Mr. G. H. Gooderham, Indian Agent, Gleichen, Alberta.

I have your letter of the 10th instant, with reference to the Crowfoot Indian Residential School. While I am not certain if the funds at our disposal will permit our purchasing all the items requested by the Principal, I would like to have more definite information regarding the type of washer, laundry extractor and bread mixer which you consider are required. No doubt, the Principal has been giving some consideration to the matter and will be able to supply definite catalogue numbers regarding each of the items. It will be more satisfactory if he supplies us with this information, as we could then endeavour to secure exactly what he thinks would be most suitable for the school.

This school has an authorized pupil enrollment of 75, but we only pay for 92.24% of this number. I presume that there are beds in the school for the number for whom grant is allowed and, consequently, we do not understand your reference to taking in new pupils this fall. According to our records, 75 pupils are all that can be accommodated at the Crowfoot School, and, for health reasons, we do not wish to see any of our residential schools overcrowded, if it can be avoided. With this in mind, we will not consider ordering the 15 beds. Inspector Schmidt has recently received mattresses from surplus supplies of the Department of National Defence. No doubt, he will send a number of these mattresses to the Crowfoot School.

R. A. Hoey,

Re: File 104-2-5

Dear Sir,

Our agent, Mr. Gooderham, has submitted your letter of the 6th inst. to me for information concerning a washer for our school.

For the past years a washer had been asked for on the yearly requisition list; we attributed the failure to provide one due to circumstances brought about by the war. As a meagre substitute for a power washer we suggested a domestic type, as some type or other was urgently needed. A machine of institutional type is by all means preferred. Our two washers in use at present are good but far too small to handle the amount of washing that a personnel of 120 accumulates. A third washer had to be discarded and it was to replace this one that a domestic type was requested. If the Dept. can give us a large one, a 40 sheet capacity, the domestic type is out of the question altogether.

I wish to make it clear to the Dept. that we have no large washer, but rather two small ones of 15 sheet size. With the acquisition of a large washer, one of the small ones could be used for the staff laundry.

The Easy Spin which was submitted to you could have been delivered in two weeks at the time we asked for a washer and that was the main reason this type was requested, thinking a larger one would be out of the question.

We trust that the above is sufficiently clear.

Yours truly,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your radiogram of the 27th ultimo, which reads:

"PLEASE OBTAIN QUOTATION FROM CALGARY OR WESTERN SOURCES ONE ONLY DOMESTIC WASHING MACHINE TWO COMPARTMENT ONE FOR WASHING AND ONE FOR DRYING CAPACITY EACH COMPARTMENT 8 LBS DRY WASH EASY SPIN DRY MODEL A1 OR SIMILAR STYLE FOR CROWFOOT INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL CLUNY ALBERTA".

On Friday, the 29th ultimo, I made enquiries in Calgary. Not knowing who handles the "Easy" Spin Dry Domestic Washer, I first called on Stanley Brock, Ltd., Manufacturers' Agents for Laundry Machinery and Supplies, at 563 - 8th Ave., West, who informed me that they did not handle domestic size washing machines; therefore they were unable to quote. They informed me that they could supply only with one of their No. 1 size belt-driven units, which consists of a Globe-Wood Washer, extractor, together with the necessary pulleys, shafting and motor -- capacity: 40 pounds, dry wash; price - $368.00 F.O.B. Cluny. They can also supply a No. 2 size, same make, capacity - 50 pounds, dry wash; at a price of $400.00. They remarked that the latter is the better buy for a school or institution such as the Crowfoot School.

From there, I went to the Canadian General Electric Company, and was told that they did not have an electric washer in stock from Coast to Coast. Mr. B.A. Chopin, the Appliance Sales Manager, very kindly phoned the Fairbanks-Morse Company, Ltd., who stated that they did not have a washer on hand, and did not know where they could get one.

I then called on the Beatty Appliance and Repair Company's representative at 814 - 6th Street, West, who suggested one of their machines -- size 15 pounds -- which he thought could be procured from their head office at Fergus, Ontario. He gave me an illustrated pamphlet which I am enclosing herewith.

I then went to the Northern Electric Company, 709 - 8th Avenue, West, and was told that they did not have a washing machine on hand, had not had for some time past, and did not know where or when they could get one.

I then called on the Wilson Electric Supplies, Limited, 335 - 8th Ave., West, who said that they handled the "Easy" Washer, domestic size (as mentioned in your radiogram); but that they did not have one on hand, and did not know whether they could get one. I was told that Mr. Wilson, of that firm, was in Eastern Canada and was expected back at the week-end; that they would bring the matter to his attention. I phoned today, and was told that Mr. Wilson had been contacted, and that there is not a machine of the model specified in your radiogram, to be obtained. They added, "We could probably supply you, later this month, with a ringer machine -- capacity 6 pounds; we are expecting to receive one or two, but we do not even know what model will be sent us; there are three models of "Easy" ringer machines made." It would therefore appear that it will be impossible to get an "Easy" two-compartment machine.
I then called Harrison and Crosfield (Canada) Limited, who stated: "We do not have the household type of washing machines; we have only the institution and laundry size; we do not have a combined washer and drier. I suggest that you have your Branch at Ottawa contact the Beaver Laundry Machinery Co., Limited, of Toronto, who have an Agent in Ottawa; they could discuss the whole matter."

I then called the A.W. Maguire Company of 514 - 11th Ave., West, who stated that they did not have any washing machines for sale.

I called on the Marshall-Wells Hardware, Company, Ltd., who informed me that they have not had an electric, domestic washer in stock for several months, and have no idea when they will have one, or what model; nor have they any idea where one could be located in a retail store.

I then called on the J.H. Ashdown Hardware Company, who informed me that they did not have a domestic washing machine on hand, nor did they know when they would receive any, or what model or make. However, they very kindly stated that they would write - Air Mail - to the manufacturers of the "Easy" washing machine in Toronto, making enquiries as to whether it would be possible to get a machine for our Branch, who could obtain the necessary priority rights for the purchase of same. Upon receipt of word from Ashdown's I will communicate with you further.

I beg to enclose herewith copy of a letter I have addressed to the Departmental Purchasing Agent.

I was at the Blackfoot Agency on the 6th instant, and called at the Crowfoot School, and looked over the washing machines and extractor, which consist of:

Washing Machines: There are two of these all-metal washers, same size, Serial Numbers 3043 and 3044, manufactured by the Toronto Laundry Machine Company, of Toronto, Canada; these are belt-driven; The inner, revolving drum being 30 inches long and 30 inches in diameter, would, I am told, classify them as having 40 pounds dry wash capacity.

The outer casing or shells of both machines became worn and leaked, and were renewed with heavy galvanized iron some years ago. These machines are still working, but I am told these two units are too small for the amount of washing that has to be done at this school. When they were installed by the Department when the school was built (in 1913, I believe) they were intended to do the work for 60 pupils; today there are 51 boys and 51 girls in residence, plus the personnel.

A third -- small-sized, second-hand washing machine, which the school picked up and repaired, was used for a time as a supplementary washer; this has been discarded (taken out and junked) being completely worn out and useless.

Extractor: The all-metal extractor -- also belt-driven -- now in use, is referred to as a 15-inch inner basket size, capacity 20 pounds dry wash. I am told that this extractor was a gift from the Sisters of the Cranbrook, B.C. Hospital, it being too small for their requirements. This extractor is now in very poor shape: The cast iron frame or arm which holds the spindle shaft, having broken has been welded twice, and again has a flaw and may break at any time.

This extractor is also one of the Toronto Laundry Machine Company's make; this Company closed and were bought out in 1912 by the Canadian Laundry Company. I am informed that these models -- both washer and extractor -- have not been made since, and have been off the market for several years, and that repairs cannot be got.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re Crowfoot Residential School.

An addition to this school was erected in the winter of 1938; it has not been weather proof. The east wall - tile, brick and cement - has cracked badly in spots; no outside storm windows were put on, though inner French type windows were but these do not keep out the wintry gales. The foundation has no footings, so far as can be ascertained and as the building settles, the cracks in the wall become bigger.

I took carpenter contractors over it, in company with the principal, recently. Nothing of a permanent repair to the wall is suggested at this time but I recommend that outside storm windows be put on, and the cracks in the wall be packed with Oakum and Mortar.

The ground floor is classrooms and the basement is the boys' playroom; in cold wintry weather it cannot be properly heated.

There is no door exit to play grounds from the basement but a window was removed and replaced by a small door; the boys crawl through this. The carpenters can make a door - 3'x5' - unto the ground level by putting steps and a small platform inside. This is recommended.

The windows must be specially made and it is our experience that this may take some time; it is known they will cost over $100.00.

(OVER)

Re: Crowfoot Indian Res. School.

A jacket heater, and a water front for the kitchen range at this institution must be supplied. The estimated cost, installed, is $110.00.

The new principal found that neither the heater nor the water front had been cleared of scale and became so corroded that they burst, leaving the institution without hot water.

The local plumber was contacted and upon our instructions he ordered a water front from Winnipeg and a No. 12 jacket heater from Calgary. Trust this is approved.

G. H. Gooderham,

5. The Principal is very much worried over fire hazards for the school and deprecates the ruling of the Department which pays the salary of the night watchman for the winter months only. He says that fire hazards exist at all times when the children are in school, and he would appreciate it if the Department would pay the salary for the whole year or at least for ten months, as it was done formerly. He also states that with $40.00 it is now impossible to secure the services of a first class man and he also desires that this be raised to $60.00 per month.

6. The root cellar is very old and needs re-building completely. Would it be possible this year or early next year to have the sum of $1500.00 included in the estimates for this purpose?

7. The school received two sewing machines from the Department but there are still three machines that ought to be replaced, immediately. You may judge of their age by the following serial numbers: G.1859599 - JA 532428 - IB34978. If at all possible, he wishes to have Tailor's instead of the ordinary house machines.

8. The stable has not been painted for a very long time and really needs two coats of paint. Would the Department supply two gallons of black stain and twenty gallons of S.W.P. bright red. The school did receive last year ten gallons of paint with which the poultry house and the shop were painted. Moreover twenty gallons of white paint are also needed for general interior and exterior painting of the school. To the above should be added ten gallons of linseed oil, three gallons of turpentine and four paint brushes. It would also be very much appreciated if the Department could supply twenty-five gallons of liquid wax which could be used with great advantage in the classrooms and halls.

9. The school itself, particularly the roof, has not been painted in several years and something should be done about it. The quantity of paint required for this job could be ascertained by writing the Agent. That is something which ought to be done early next year.

10. The floors of the dormitories, of the girls' recreation room and of the refectory are all in very poor condition and must be replaced. In spots, the rough floor can be seen through the holes in the top floor.

11. The tables and benches of the dining room have been in use since the school was built. They have been so often repaired that they hardly hold together. It is now
proposed that the Department supply the material and that new tables and benches be made by the boys under their new teacher. In order to make the tables last longer it is suggested that linoleum be used as a top finish.

12 - Linoleum is desired for several rooms particularly the Indians' parlor, the hall in the basement and that on the second floor leading to the Chapel.

Dear Sir,

Re. Pump at the Crowfoot Indian School Cluny.

This pump was installed but does not work satisfactory. As Father A. Charron was in to see me today, I may say that when this pump was under consideration no allowance was made to pump down to suction. The pump now installed will pump to suction. And when doing so the efficiency of the pump drops both in pressure and delivery. Under circumstances I am prepared to leave the pump now installed. To supply water for the School until another pump is put in its place.

Date: December 3rd., 1946.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Water Supply,
Crowfoot School, Cluny.

Crowfoot Residential School, Cluny, is supplied with water from a flowing artesian well. This well has been in use now for over ten years, according to the Principal, and the flow is diminishing rapidly. Besides this, the pipes are badly rusted and corroded.

Supply of water has dropped rapidly during the last month and there is not now enough water to supply all demands, even with careful use. It is feared that the well is quitting, as all artesian wells do after a number of years, and if this is found to be true authority is hereby asked to drill another artesian well.

It is estimated here that we will have to drill 120 feet at a price of $1.75 per foot; besides this of course there will be the necessary casing.

R. D. Regan,
Clerk-In-Charge.

ATRMAIL

Ottawa, 10 December 1946.

Mr. H.D. Ragan, Clerk in Charge,
GLEICHUN, Alta.

We have received your letter of the 3rd instant and are extremely sorry to learn that the Crowfoot School is having trouble with its water supply.

Please let me know the approximate location of where it is proposed to dig a new well. You should give the range and latitude.

You mentioned that the well will have to be drilled to a depth of 120 feet. What assurance have you that we will obtain water at that depth? We have had a number of unhappy experiences in endeavouring to obtain water on other reserves in southern Alberta and before proceeding we intend to submit the matter to the Surveys and Engineering branch with a view to obtaining the opinion of their water experts.

Please let me have the information requested in this letter by airmail.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Reference your 104-2-5 (W.T. 1) of the 12th instant re the Crowfoot School water supply.

The proposed new well will be dug on the Southwest quarter of Section 32, Township 21, Range 21 West of the Fourth Meridian, approximately ten miles south of the 51st Latitude and east of the 114th Longitude.

The only assurance we have that water will be reached between the depths of 100 and 125 feet is that this is an artesian flowing well area and water has always been obtained at a depth less than 120 feet. In fact, flowing wells have been dug by hand as shallow as thirty feet. On the Crowfoot School grounds, however, it has been necessary to go to 100 feet.

It is just possible that the reduction in flow of the existing well is due to corroding and rusting pipe. Mr. Michael, our well expert, states however that it is likely any tampering with this pipe will stop the flow altogether - as artesian wells are peculiar in this respect. As soon as he can spare the time he has promised to go into this thoroughly to ascertain if the well can be saved. In the meantime, however, we thought it advisable to obtain authority to drill a new well, if this was found necessary, so that it could be done with as little delay as possible.

R.D. [Signature]
Clerk-in-Charge.

Re: Well at Crowfoot School.

I beg to report that the new well drilled at the Crowfoot Indian Residential School last April has been proved a very good supply of water but considerable settlement of sediment with some fine sand. They have been pumping it steady all summer with apparently good results and it has cleared of sediment to a great extent.

The purposes of this letter is to fore-warn you of considerable more expense that is a pump and motor, pipe for the well and piping the same to cistern also a shelter over the pump, it will also entail cement sump for frost purposes. The reason that none of this work has been completed is on account that I did not want to go to unnecessary expense before the well had proved itself.

I am not prepared to give a detail estimate but I am of the opinion by the time the pump and motor and necessary work is done it will run well over $500.00. I would ask you to keep this in mind when you deal with Crowfoot Indian School. Details will follow shortly.

Re: Crowfoot School - Root House.

Reference to the above and your Purchase Order #10433, dated April 25, 1945. This Purchase Order originated out of your letter dated December 15, 1945, and Mr. Gooderham's reply thereto dated December 22, 1945. The material for the Root cellar was supplied in the sum of $201.76 from Crown Lumber Co., Gleichen, Alta.

However in discussing the matter with the Principal of the School, Father Charron, he stated that he understood that the Department were going to pay for the labor for rebuilding the root house. However there does not appear to be any correspondence to that effect.

In checking over the present root house I find it in very poor condition and badly in need of replacement. In order to arrive at a conclusion I had qualified cement workers and carpenters go down to the school and check the root house over carefully.

The following is our findings:- that owing to two years more of deterioration more work and material is needed, the present entrance having caved in. Extra material required.

- 42 sacs of cement,
- 27 yards of gravel (will be supplied by school),
- 250 ft. of Ship Lap,
- 18 pieces of 2x4 - 12' long,
- 12 " 2x6 - 12' (Beams 2)
- 4 " 2x6 - 14' (Upright)

Hardware: - Nails, hinges, etc.

Approximate cost of extra material: $125.00

Skilled Cement and Carpenter Labor: Installing forms, taking out forms, building entrance to root house; Size of Root House 12 ft wide x 22 ft long x 7 ft high with cement roof: Approximate cost: $625.00

The above in addition to the material supplied on Purchase Order #10433. School to do all excavating and rough labor.

I might remark that I am in no way responsible for this expenditure as it originated before I took over and an estimate of labor should have been made at the time.

I would further say that the present root house is falling down and should be replaced somehow. Regret that it was not put into 1947/48 Estimates.

Your reply by return mail would be appreciated.

W. P. B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept of Mines & Res., Ottawa.

Attention: Mr. B. F. Neary, Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re: Crowfoot School - Boys' Entrance.

I beg to report that the entrance to the Boys Cloak Room in the basement has always been through a window about 2'6" x 3'6" with 5 steps from the window to the floor of the cloak room. Apparently this has continued since 1937 when the new wing was erected. This direct entrance into the Boys' Cloak Room was made in order to avoid a long walk with muddy shoes through the main corridor in the basement - main entrance in the centre of the building and boys' cloak room and playground are in the east end of the building and east side.

Since the window only gives half height to the door, I would suggest that the entrance be enlarged to full height door that a stairs be put into the boys' cloak room from the entrance.

I would also point out that the foundation under the present window door exit has a very large crack endangering the east wall of the school.

I would strongly recommend that this exit be made into a safe entrance for the boys and that the foundation be repaired at an estimate cost of $100.00.

W. P. B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Well at Crowfoot Res. School.

Reference to my letter of July 30th last, I beg to ask for authority to now make the necessary installation of an Electric Pump, pump head, motor cylinder and pipes, and connecting same to the present water supply—this new installation being an auxiliary supply of fairly soft water. The necessary frost pits and entrance to the same from school boiler room, concrete work, material and skilled labor supplied for $450.00. School to do necessary excavating. Pump installation complete with electrical work for $369.00—total of $819.00.

The well has been continuously tested all summer and found good as to supply water, analysed—found very good, only one exception a few grains of sand have shown up in every sample. We have had a borrowed pump installed all summer when this is taken out, through examination of this cylinder, we will ascertain if the sand is causing much wear and if the cylinder does show much wear, the above concrete plans will be reduced by approximately $200.00. The reason if the wear is shown from past experience the life of the well might be limited to 10 to 15 years.

I would appreciate your authority by Air Mail.

W. F. B. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

Re Pump for Crowfoot School.

Reference to your letter of Sept. 2nd last and further to my letter of Aug. 28th last and I appreciate the contents thereof and am sorry I was not clear re the pump. I will deal with your letter as follows:

1. Repairs to Boys entrance to the school $100.00 now underway. Should be completed by end of month—weather permitting.
2. Labor for digging frost pits and entrance to the same concrete work etc in connection with the new well $450.00. This work is now underway however I would point out that the school are doing all the digging. I only estimated for the skilled concrete labor and material.
3. Re Electric Pump. I herewith enclose Estimate of L. Michael, Gleichen, Alta in the sum of $365.00. In this connection I would point out that he is quoting on a reconditioned second hand pump which is in excellent condition. I regretted that I did not point this out, as no new pumps are available either here or in Calgary. The Crowfoot School are supplying the motor, we are not able to purchase a motor of this size anywhere, and they had one available, that is the school. The pipe we are using in the well is second hand and will have to be replaced, we expect the new pipe available any day. I might say that we have been using the above pump on loan from Mr. Michael’s all summer in testing the well. He will however recondition the pump before installing. This is an awkward explanation but just one of those things growing out of short supply, trusting the quotation is satisfactory.

The last paragraph of your letter, I have included the cost of rebuilding the Root house in the 1948-1949 Estimates.

Respectfully submitted,

W.P.B. Dugan,
Indian Agent.

Attached hereto you will find a copy of a letter from Mr. R. D. Hagan, Superintendent of the Blood Indian Agency, in answer to a letter which was sent out from this office regarding surplus government buildings, and particularly regarding certain buildings located at the R.C.A.F. Training Center near Macleod.

Mr. Hagan has suggested, as you will note, that two Link Trainer buildings from the Macleod and Peaceau stations be moved on to the Blood Reserve as additional classrooms at the two residential schools. I recently inspected these buildings, and I am satisfied they would answer the purpose very well for some years, if they were not dismantled and set up again.

Mr. Hagan had an experienced contractor, Mr. Kaufman, who has moved similar buildings from the stations for the P.E.I.R.A. and other concerns, examine them. This gentleman states that he could move them in the winter time across the river.

Please bear in mind that the only time he could move them is during the winter months, as they are too large to cross ordinary bridges and must be taken over when the ice is strong.

If these buildings are still available and it was agreed that it was good business to move them to the schools, the cost is a plus item in the Education Vote, is it not? I recommend they be secured, if available, and moved.

Regarding Building No. 12, Recreation Center, Macleod, it should be noted that this building be located, if at all possible, near the school hall. The Bloods have no hall, and this building needed not only as a social center but also for meetings. The Band fund is small, and I believe that the cost of moving this building should be charged against Welfare Account. All expenses could end and would be, I am sure, borne by ourselves.

If authority was given to Mr. Hagan, this building could be moved intact and placed on a suitable site near the agency headquarters.
Careful consideration has been given to the moving of all of these buildings during the winter months across the river, before submitting the request that they be requisitioned. It is hoped they are still available, and that you will agree that they are a valuable asset to the Blood Reserve, and will act promptly to try to secure them.

G. H. Gooderham,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

ATTENTION: H.F. Henry

RE: Crowfoot Root House

Reference your letter of Nov. 30, I beg to report that I have a lot of explaining to do in this connection so far, that owing to heavy drainage water conditions last spring which totally inundated the old Root House at the Crowfoot School. Father Charron was prepared to do the excavating for the Root house in a new location. I informed him that the expenditure would have to be kept around $750.00. This meant that the skilled labour would have to be cut about one half, but more materials would be required. I regret that I miss used your letter of authority in making local purchase of materials and not Requisitioning for same. Father Charron had a supply of material on hand, which we used some of rather than purchase from Crown Lumber at Gleichen 10 miles away from the job, and I am attaching hereto, Voucher 781 in payment of same, in favour of Father Charron.

My records show the total cost of the Concrete Root House charged to our Branch, size 12 x 24 inside measurements, is approximately $765.00. Father Charron paid for the excavation over
in the sum of $260.00, supplied 75 yds of gravel at $2.60 per yard. His own men put in 176 hours of labour. He also electrically wired the Root House at his own expense.

I am sure this Root House will last longer than any of us who are now in the service, where if we had repaired the old Root House, we would have had very little satisfaction and a repeat job in a few years.

I appear to be transgressing the purchase Regulations but I assure you without intention and they have been cases of expediency.

W.E.B. Pugh
Superintendent

ATTENTION B.F. Neary

Re: Crowfoot Root House

Reference your letter of Nov. 30, I beg to report that I have a lot of explaining to do in this connection in so far, that owing to heavy drainage water conditions last spring which totally inundated the old Root House at the Crowfoot School. Father Charron was prepared to do the excavating for the Root House in a new location. I informed him that the expenditure would have to be kept around $750.00. This meant that the skilled labour would have to be cut about one half, but more materials would be required. I regret that I miss used your letter of authority in making local purchase of materials and not Requisitioning for same. Father Charron had a supply of material on hand, which we used some of rather than purchase from Crown Lumber at Gleichen 10 miles away from the job, and I am attaching hereto, Voucher 781 in payment of same, in favour of Father Charron.

My records show the total cost of the Concrete Root House charged to our Branch, size 12 x 24 inside measurements, is approximately $765.00. Father Charron paid for the excavation in the sum of $260.00, supplied 75 yds of gravel at $2.60 per yard. His own men put in 176 hours of labour. He also electrically wired the Root House at his own expense.

I am sure this Root House will last longer than any of us who are now in the service, where if we had repaired the old Root House, we would have had very little satisfaction and a repeat job in a few years.

I appear to be transgressing the purchase regulations, but I assure you without intention and they have been cases of expediency.

(sgd) W.P.B. Pugh,

With reference to your telegram of March 21st and our reply of today's date, it is regretted that you were not previously notified of the intention to ship the oven to the Crowfoot School.

However, as intimated in today's telegram, we knew this oven was surplus to requirements at the Lac la Ronge School, but we thought that possibly the management of that school might decide to use it. Accordingly we wired them that if the oven was not needed, it could be shipped to the Crowfoot School, as we were not aware that it was too large for that school. The Superintendent, however, neglected to advise us of the shipment.

It is hoped that the oven will be suitable for the Blood R.C. School, and it would be appreciated if you would request the Principal of that school to advise us if he is taking it.

April 24th, 1919.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I presented the matter of change of site of the Red Deer Institute to Edmonton to the Executive of our Board yesterday. They were unanimous in endorsing the scheme and authorized me to continue negotiations with the Department in view of making the change. The Board is agreeable to giving up the site at Red Deer and the ranch at Morley towards helping the scheme financially. Of course it is understood in doing so that the interests of our educational work at Morley shall stand on its own merits and that this sale of the ranch will in no way prejudice our educational interests in Southern Alberta. I hope that the Department will find the Red Deer farm may be purchased by the military authorities for work that they require in caring for our returned soldiers.

As soon as I return to Brandon I will communicate with your commissioner, Mr. Graham, and try to arrange for a suitable date to accompany him to Edmonton to look over all prospective sites.

Yours sincerely,

TF/M
