Dear Mr. Scott,

I have just returned from Alberta. While there I attended the Conference. The situation at Red Deer Institute has reached a crisis and the question of changing the site to Edmonton must be decided in the near future. This was the unanimous conviction of a committee appointed to look into the situation. Dr. Endicott, Secretary of the Foreign Department of our Mission Board and myself were appointed to interview the Minister of Indian Affairs. Dr. Chown would have been on this committee had it been possible for him to attend. As he is going to Newfoundland this was not possible until after the 10th of July. The date that will suit Dr. Endicott and myself would be Friday, the 20th or Monday the 23rd. Would it be possible for you to arrange for us to meet the Minister on either of those dates? You will understand that I am assuming that you will be present too at the interview. This of course from my point of view is a necessity. Address your reply to me at the Methodist Conference, Winnipeg, and if the strike is still on it might be well to send a copy to Brandon so that I would be sure to receive it.

Deputy Superintendent General.
The Superintendent of Indian Education received a communication from Rev. Joseph Woodsworth, Principal of the Red Deer Institute, re the financial situation, number of pupils in attendance and other matters of vital importance in connection with the Red Deer Institute. On account of the crisis that has been reached in connection with the work at Red Deer, it was thought advisable to have a conference of a few who were directly interested and Mr. Woodsworth. This was done at the Alberta Conference in Calgary. Mr. Woodsworth presented the case to the following and his presentation is herewith appended.

Rev. S. D. Chown, D.D., General Secretary of Foreign Missions,
and the following Superintendents - Rev. T. C. Buchanan, D.D., Rev. Thos. Powell, Rev. Arthur Banner and Rev. T. Ferrier, and the Hon. W. H. Cushing. After hearing Mr. Woodsworth's presentation of the case the opinion prevailed that our educational work for our Indian people in Northern Alberta would be better served by changing the site from Red Deer to Edmonton. As a result of this Conference the Secretary of the Foreign Department and the Superintendent of Indian Education on June 23rd interviewed Mr. Dunham C. Scott, Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs. Mr. Scott received us very cordially and sympathetically. He concurred in our presentation of the case and is in hearty sympathy with the proposed change of site from RED DEER to EDMONTON, but pointed out that no money could be secured by Vote of Parliament at its present session in as much as the estimates and supplementary estimates were all completed and Parliament would be closing in a few days. He, however, assured us that he had $60,000 in the Supplementary Estimates and if passed by Parliament would be at the disposal of the Methodist Church and that we as representatives of the Church would be at liberty as far as the Government was concerned to say in what direction and for why
purpose this $60,000 should be used. Its present proposal is that it should be used for small buildings required at Mancey, Brandon, Norway House, Coqualeetza and some Day Schools on Reserves. All of which are greatly needed. At the same time we are of the opinion that the general interests of our entire work would be better served by the expenditure of this $60,000 for our educational work this year in making the change from Red Deer to Edmonton assure. If we decided to expend it in the purchase of a site and the commencement of a building in Edmonton, Mr. Scott would heartily recommend the expenditure of this $60,000 as we suggested, to the Minister. It being understood that the Minister must give his sanction to the whole scheme.

We also discussed the property at MOREY which consists of some fifteen hundred acres of ranching land upon which the Methodist Church erected the McDougall Orphanage some thirty years ago. There is also a building that has been used for class room purposes. The other outbuildings are not of much value. This land is owned by the Government. There is also a section and three-quarters of land in connection with the Red Deer Institute. We proposed that both of these properties should be sold and that the Methodist Church should receive credit for the same and the proceeds be put into the new plant at Edmonton. Mr. Scott assured us that this would have to meet the approval of Parliament but that he would strongly recommend that this be done.

We recommended to Mr. Scott that a Commission consisting of representatives from the Indian Department and of the Methodist Church visit the following Reserves - HOBENA, WHITE FISH LAKE, GOOD FISH LAKE, SADDLE LAKE, WHITE WHALE LAKE. These form a Constituency that would be served by a school situated in Edmonton, Edmonton being geographically in the centre.
And, that this Commission secure if possible the endorsement of the Indian people through their Councils and others interested, to the proposed new school and a written promise that they will support the school if built in the vicinity of Edmonton.

And, that this Commission further be instructed and empowered to select the new site. This received the approval of Mr. Scott.

From the representations made by Mr. Woodsworth, the principal of Red Deer School, we recommend that the school be closed with the dismissal of the children for holidays. We also recommend that if there are orphan children who have no place to go that they be transferred to Brandon until the new school is built. Mr. Scott assures us that this will meet with the approval of the Department and that the Department will pay the cost of transportation. We also recommend that Mr. Woodsworth keep the farm going and retain such members of the staff as will be required to gather and secure the harvest and that he spend all the time possible during the Conference year in visiting the reserves for the purpose of popularising the scheme with the Indians as much as possible.

ALL OF WHICH IS RESPECTFULLY SUBMITTED.
Dear Doctor Endicott:

The following is the statement or report which you requested me to send to you. There are a number of angles from which the problem may be approached. I shall try to present them all, and relate them to the main issue. They may be taken up under the following heads:

(a) The Red Deer problem past, and present.
(b) Attendance.
(c) Plant.
(d) The Edmonton proposition.
(e) Financial.
(f) Temporary closing of the school.

The problem we are at present facing in regard to the future of the Red Deer Industrial Institute is by no means a matter of recent growth. It is the result of the development of events of years past. Things have now reached a climax. For a number of years workers among the Indians of Alberta have realized that this school has not been fulfilling its function as an educational institution for the Indians. In the FIRST place it has acquired a bad name among the Indians through years of mismanagement. Second it has been in the wrong place from the first, being too far from the homes of the Indian and more than once the lack of pupils has been a menace to the prosperity of the Institute. About ten years ago a special commission recommended that the school be closed, and boarding schools be established on the reserves. On the strength of this recommendation, which to the Indian amounted to a promise, the Red Deer school was filled to its capacity. Seven years ago the school reached its maximum attendance. At this time Mr. Barrer resigned as principal when he found it impossible to carry out his program, and I was appointed in his place and carried out the Industrial School plans. For a time, in hopes that the Boarding Schools might yet be established on the reserves, the Indians continued to send their children, and for two years a splendid attendance was maintained. However at the end of this time the Government definitely rejected the proposals of the Mission Board and decided to continue the old policy. As soon as this was known to the Methodist Indians of Alberta, a meeting was held at Hobema at which it was decided to boycott the Red Deer School.

ATTENDANCE.

For two years following this decision not a single child was admitted to the Institute. Since then a few have come in but many of the have come under compulsion. At the end of June 1919 we shall have but forty children in residence at the school. It will thus be seen that the
boycott has been effective, and that in spite of every effort to maintain the attendance. The result of this reduced enrolment makes further operations most difficult and with little hope of improvement. This applies particularly to the household work where next year there will be only twelve girls old and young to do the work of the institution. Under our present system this will be almost impossible.

BUILDINGS - In connection with the problem of policy and attendance has been the matter of plant. For a good many years it has been a recognized fact that the buildings have been entirely insufficient for the requirements of the institution. Only sufficient has been spent year by year to keep them from falling to pieces. Of course during the war we realized that extensive repairs were impossible and the principal of your school all during this time of tension refrained from making requests for repairs or buildings other than were absolutely necessary. This policy was followed regarding expenditure by both Government and Church. Lack of accommodation in various ways has now become a decided hindrance to our work. The buildings are in such a condition, and the whole plant so dilapidated that it seriously affects the morale of our school life, and enormously increases the difficulty of operation. And not only has it retarded our work but the General Board today is paying hundreds if not thousands of dollars because of this condition of the Government plant.

With the closing of the war and the necessity and probability of extensive changes the question of future policy again arose. I felt that in view of the past failure of Red Deer in attendance, location, and appeal to the Indian, it was questionable if it was right for the Missionary Society to allow the Indian Department to put large sums of money into this plant without first a clear understanding of the whole situation. It must be understood that to make the plant at all suitable to the management, not only must the main buildings be entirely rebuilt but the whole arrangements of outbuildings and stables must be taken into consideration. Then came the thought; even though the Government gives us a modern plant we will be no nearer our end in serving the Indian. The school will still be a drag, largely because of its position, the increasing protest from the Indian is "it is too far to send our children".

THE EDMONTON PROPOSITION

With this came an idea for a solution of the problem, at least in part, namely, transferring the institution to Edmonton. This move would place the school almost exactly in the centre of our Indian Constituency and bring us more intimately in touch with them. The proposition met with hearty approval by all who were interested including the General Board, and the Department. Since making the suggestion, Mr. Perrier and I have made selections of possible sites near Edmonton, and negotiations are in progress to make purchase of land and complete arrangements with the Government.

THE IMMEDIATE CLOSING OF RED DEER -

Since making the above suggestion, matters of finance, attendance staff, and policy, has become so acute, that I felt that immediate action must be taken to meet the situation. With this in view I recommended that the school be closed 30th June 1919 to be reopened as soon as possible in Edmonton. My reasons for this suggestion are as follows:
Financial - It will save the Missionary Society about $10,000.00.

(2) It will give me, as principal, an opportunity of doing valuable work on the reserves in the interests of the school doing the interim. It will also enable me to give attention to the closing of this school (which is not a small task) and also be on hand to keep in close touch with the establishing of the new institution in Edmonton.

(3) If we close immediately we shall retain the initiative in regard to the guidance of school affairs. Otherwise this initiative will pass from our hands to that of the Indians, and this is not desirable. This last reason seems to me to be the strongest of all. Not even a large money grant would suffice to take the place of loss of initiative. I cannot emphasize this point too strongly in its application to this problem. To me, looking at it from every standpoint, we will gain much by closing at once. This school has had its day and without further blinking at facts we should insist upon new and proper conditions in operating our school.

FINANCIAL - At the end of June 1919 we shall have a deficit of about $5000.00 which the Missionary Society will have to meet in some way. Besides this, this institution, if it is operated next year will cost the Missionary Society between six and seven thousand dollars. If the school is closed nearly this entire amount of between ten and twelve thousand dollars will be saved.

This in brief is the position of the school both past and present. There are so many phases of the question that are familiar to me that it is somewhat difficult to present them in a formal manner and in their proper light and relationship. However this short statement may be of value to you.

As principal now, for six and a half years, I have watched developments very closely, and have endeavored to deal with problems as they presented themselves. I believe that with my experience behind me I have a pretty fair grasp of the essential needs of this institution and of our Indian work in Alberta. From time to time I have advised the authorities both Church and Government of the conditions which exist so that the present situation is not new. I have been planning for the new school in Edmonton and am ready to go into this new scheme with energy and enthusiasm. If in dealing with these matters you require further information or detail or my presence, I shall be glad to serve the Missionary Society in the interests of the Indian.

J. F. WOODSWORTH.

MEMORANDUM

Hon. Mr. Meighen -

In 1892 the Red Deer Industrial school was established at Red Deer, Alberta, and has been conducted since that time under the auspices of the Methodist Church. There are 1140 acres of land in connection with the institution. This school was designed to take care of the Methodist pupilage in the northern part of the provinces of Alberta - the Bobbema, Edmonton and Laddie Lake Agencies. The school has not prospered as it should, due principally to two facts: first, its location is too far distant from the recruiting grounds, second, mismanagement in periods on the part of the church authorities.

Some two years' ago the Methodist Church had under consideration the question of closing the school and establishing some smaller boarding schools adjacent to the reserves from which they draw their largest number of pupils. This scheme, however, was never carried out.

The buildings are all in a dilapidated condition and previous to the war we had under consideration the erection of new buildings or extensive repairs to the existing ones. The Church, however, now represents that it is impossible for them to continue the work on the present location and they wish to remove to a site near the city of Edmonton, which would be almost in the centre of their constituency. The establishment of a new school in this location will entail a large expenditure in the purchase of land, the price of which in the vicinity of Edmonton is very high, and in the erection of modern buildings.

The proposal of the church is that the Indian agencies above referred to should be canvassed with a view to securing the support of the Indians to the proposition, by way of a definite promise to send their children to the school, and that the Department should dispose of the Red Deer property and also the property in connection with the old McDougall Orphanage at Morley on the Stony Reserve, purchase a new site this year and proceed with the erection of the buildings at as early a date as possible.

The matter has been discussed with me by the representatives of the Methodist Church, and I wish now to lay the proposal before you. I am not yet convinced of the advisability of embarking on this scheme, I think the matter should be very carefully considered. The suggestion has been made that an informal commission, on which the Department would be represented, should meet at Edmonton during the first week in September. This, I think, would be the proper course to take and I would propose to have Mr. Graham represent the Department. In passing I may mention that Mr. Graham is disposed to favour the removal to the vicinity of Edmonton. We must not, however, take any preliminary steps that would involve us in any obligation until fully satisfied as to the merits of the proposition. At the same time the
matter is one of grave importance to the church.

With your approval I shall arrange for the meeting of this commission at a date that will be convenient to Mr. Graham.

Indian Work on Prairies Makes Good Progress

Rev. Thompson Ferrier Tells of Methodist Church Educational Work

Rev. Thompson Ferrier, superintendent of Indian Missions for the Methodist church of Canada, who occupied the pulpit at the First Methodist Church on Sunday morning has left the city for Regina where he will spend several days on the good work of supervising and directing the educational work among the Indians of that province. Before leaving Edmonton Mr. Ferrier was interviewed by The Edmonton Journal and gave interesting facts regarding the educational work being done among the Indians by the Methodist church among the Indians of the prairies.

The interest which has been shown in the program in Alberta and with particular reference to the Alberta Institute just north of the city a bright outlook was prophesied for the future work among the prairie Indians.

Have Waiting List

"The educational work in British Columbia and in Ontario is much more advanced than that now being done among the Indian people than on the prairies," said Mr. Ferrier. "In the schools conducted in the two provinces mentioned we have a waiting list which has not been the experience in the case of the residential schools conducted on the prairies.

The education of the Indian boys and girls, on the whole, is very encouraging. Many of them proving themselves to be good citizens and contributing to the state. About 5,000 young Indians from the various schools and reserves being overseas, the group held gave an excellent account of themselves. Forty seven of these are buried abroad and ten of these are "buried where the poppy grows."

Mr. Ferrier makes his headquarters at Brandon, Manitoba, but during the course of his duties is called upon to visit all parts of Canada. Next Monday he goes to the Queen Charlotte Islands and on the following Sunday at Fort Smith, he will turn his face once more eastward, reaching Ottawa somewhere around February first.

New Era Appears

With the opening of the new Edmonton Institute a new era appears to open in the work of the Methodist church among the Indians of this province, according to the superintendent. The institute covers a tract of 825 acres, which was purchased for $16,000. It will be used for the splendid new $100,000 school, which will serve as a center for the province and is expected to look after the wants of the province in this direction for a long time to come.

"Indian boys and girls will come to the institute from the missions and reserves at Holeson, Duffield, "Pine Lake, Red Deer, Fish Lake, Saddle Lake and other places," said Mr. Ferrier. "There will be accommoda- tion for about 135 children and staff of twelve teachers. The boys are kept at the age of seven and are kept until they are eighteen. The girls are kept until they are fifteen years of age while the boys are taught farming, mechanics, carpentry, etc., and the care of all kinds of stock. In addition to the regular school work, religious instruction is given. The half day system is followed in the institute and here, the children spend half a day in the class room and half a day in one of the practical branches.

Purchase of Hume Farm

Mr. Ferrier stated he was particularly well satisfied with the purchase of the Hume farm. He stated that a large number of farms had been purchased recently and that many had arrived to buy the Hume acreage. Located as it is part way between Edmonton and Athabasca, and close proximity to the Sturgeon river with its abundant water power running through the property, its location is an ideal one.

This patch of ground has I understand been infested with this weed for many years before we took possession. So the matter is not new. The pest is pretty well confined to this one area. Precautions have been taken to keep all feed and produce from this field together, and the manure from the same has not been put in other fields.

It might also be mentioned that the fences around this part of the farm are in bad condition thus making it possible for horses and cattle to wander over the place, thus helping to spread the seeds. It will be remembered that the attention of the Department was drawn to the condition of the fencing on this farm and I stated that we needed some ten miles to properly protect the place. The fencing done last summer was but a small part of what is required.

I might also point out that this fall from the same section we sold a carload of wheat which graded No. I Northern with only 2% dockage and that largely consisting of ordinary cultivated oats. We are quite aware that everything about this farm is not as we would like it, I am merely trying to hold and operate
a very large farm under very trying conditions with the aid of
these men and with very limited financial resources. This condition
is inevitable until the school opens when we will be able to
attend to some of these matters under normal conditions. At present
it is simply impossible to attend to everything unless proper
financial support is given. It might be pointed out that during
the last three years the returns of this farm have been up to the
average of this district and equal to that of our neighbors. I am
glad of the criticism, but I would be glad if our worthy and
zealous neighbor had the courage to talk this matter over with me
before taking his complaint to Ottawa.

If I may be allowed to speculate a little bit, I may say
that I am not surprised at such a letter as you evidently received.
This Industrial School is not exactly popular in this vicinity. I
was given to understand that when we first took it over. The fact
that nearly a thousand acres was taken out of the municipality
and School District with the accompanying taxes explains a good
deal. We are constantly reminded of this fact. If the Department
can heal the financial sore I am sure the stinkweed will cease to
stink and otherwise cease to annoy the sensibilities of the
community.

I shall be glad to cooperate with the Department in
adjusting ourselves to the needs of this community, but until
normal conditions exist we can only do our best.

Yours Truly,

J. F. Woodsworth,
Principal.

February 12th, 1923.

Pursuant to Mr. Ferrier's conference with you on Saturday last, re the financial situation in connection with the maintenance account of the Edmonton Industrial School for the period from October 1st, 1919, to November 30th, 1922, and in answer to your request, we herewith enclose you a statement showing the Receipts and Expenditure for this period.

The Red Deer Industrial School ceased to earn per capita grants from September 30th, 1919. Since that date this enterprise, now known as the Edmonton Industrial School, has received no financial aid from the Government for maintenance. The Methodist Missionary Society has maintained a Principal and farm help on the new school property for the past three years. Due to poor harvests and low prices our entire operations have been conducted at a loss. Every energy has been bent towards preparing a farm suitable for Industrial School purposes.

A study of the statement of expenditure will show that certain items appear to be fair and just charges against parliamentary appropriation for Indian education; and had the accounts been presented at the time the expenditure was incurred, we have every reason to believe that the Department would have paid the same. The reason that the accounts were not presented was that we hoped that the entire cost of maintenance would have been met by the proceeds of the farm. The liabilities as on the 30th November last were $6,049.17. This amount would have been more serious if the Mission Board had not, since the closing of the Red Deer Institute, made grants totalling $4,200. Further, the estimated expenditure from the first of December, 1922, to the 31st of July, 1923, - at which time we hope the School will be earning a per capita grant - is at the rate of $500 per month, or a total of $4,000, when the Methodist Church, without assistance from parliamentary appropriation would be facing a total deficit of $14,249.17, including the $4,200 already advanced by the Missionary Society to maintain this institution.

The work carried on from the closing of the Red Deer School to the time when the Edmonton Institute opens its doors for Indian children cannot be considered a missionary enterprise, and whereas no opportunity to earn Government grants has obtained because of our inability to house, educate and Christianize Indian children, therefore we respectfully urge the Department of Indian Affairs to arrange for a special grant for the maintenance of the Edmonton Industrial School.
Inasmuch as the Missionary Society has paid for maintenance of this enterprise $4,200, we would respectfully request that a similar amount be granted by the Indian Department from parliamentary appropriations for Indian Education. We make this request in the hope that the receipts from the Farm sales of next harvest will meet the estimated expenditure up to the time specified.

Yours sincerely,

C.E. Manning
General Secretary, Home Missions.

T. Ferrier
Superintendent, Methodist Indian Schools.

Memorandum.

Honourable Charles Stewart:

The Red Deer Industrial School was closed and ceased to earn per capita grant from this Department, as from September 30, 1919. Since that date this Indian educational cause, now known as the Edmonton Industrial School, has received no financial aid from the Government, for maintenance. The Methodist Missionary Society has maintained a principal and certain farm help on the new school property for the past three years. Due to poor harvests and low prices, the operations have been conducted at a loss. Every energy has been bent towards preparing a farm suitable for industrial school purposes.

The activity, from the closing of the Red Deer School to the time when the Edmonton Institute opens its doors for Indian children, cannot be considered a missionary or church enterprise. The Rev. Principal and the Church have had no opportunity to earn government maintenance grants, because of their inability to house, educate and Christianize Indian children. The Methodist Missionary Society has approached me by deputation, and now by letter, with the request that this Department, for maintenance purposes, make a grant similar to that which has been made from church funds.

The Methodist Church has paid $4,200 during the past three years, for the maintenance of the Edmonton Industrial School. The net liability, as on November 30th, last, was $5,240.66 and consisted of a bank overdraft of $3,670 and outstanding accounts. The Missionary Society hope that, if this Department can make a grant of $4,200, the remainder of the deficit and the maintenance expenses for the current months can be met from the farm proceeds in the fall of this year.

In the Supplementary Estimates, 1922-23, $75,000 was voted to commence work on the new main building. It is proposed to let the contract early in the building season and have the funds provided expended for materials and labour during the months of March and April. The funds necessary to make the special grant requested could be taken from the $75,000 already voted.

As the maintenance of the Edmonton Industrial School is a fair and just charge against parliamentary appropriation, and as the Methodist Missionary Society has already paid the earlier deficits, I respectfully recommend that you give your authority for a special grant of $4,200 to the principal of the school. A cheque, if directed, will be deposited to cover the overdraft and to pay the outstanding accounts.

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Sir:

In the new Indian Residential School now nearing completion at Edmonton the Department has installed a heating system and a lighting system of the highest standard obtainable, but in order to give the results desired it is absolutely necessary that this equipment receive the proper attention at all times, from a man fully competent to carry out these duties. MUST GUARANTEE THAT EVERY INDIAN CHILD GETS EDUCATION

So Declares Hon. Charles Stewart in Unveiling Memorial Tablet at the Indian School Near St. Albert Which Was Officially Opened on Thursday

"We want a guarantee that every Indian child will be given a free education," was the request made by Hon. Charles Stewart, Superintendent General of Indian affairs, and Minister of the Interior, in connection with the fact that Indian educational institutions, both in this province and other districts, has resulted in the opening of an Indian residential school in the midst of the white district near St. Albert.

The best we can do for this great people, from whom we took their names and who gave them children," declared Mr. Stewart, in unveiling the memorial tablet on Thursday to commemorate the occasion.

Large crowds attended the official opening ceremonies, coming from great distances, and Indians and whites mingled in the new white-walled building.

Chief Samson Speaks

Chief Samson of the Edmonton Reserve was the official native spokesman and delivered an inspiring address to the gathering. Also present was the Rev. Mr. Steinler, also a Cree Indian.

Representatives of official and scholastic groups were numerous. Provincial Secretary Mr. Agar, Agriculture M. A. Craig, who is also chairman of the Board of Education, presided over the proceedings; Mr. M. Bradshaw, Western Commissioner of Indian Affairs, was present; Mr. F. Woodworth, superintendent of Methodist Indian schools; Mr. F. W. Woodworth, principal of the new school; the Rev. C. E. Manning, general-secretary of Methodist Church; and the Rev. F. Stacy McCall, principal of the Alberta College North, were also present.

A Change in Life

Mr. Steinler addressed the gathering at the conclusion of the official opening ceremonies, saying that the right and duty of the Government was to confer children every possible educational chance. He said that the north country several years ago had improved considerably, with the necessity for providing more intensive facilities for native children, and with this end in view he had been successful in inducing the Government to provide an additional $400,000 for this purpose.

When he first took charge of the Indian Department, he found it necessary to reduce expenditure throughout the country as well as any other, but he hoped that within the next few years, many more schools would be built throughout the Dominion.

He had been asked that every facility for education should be given to Indian children in return for concessions made by the Government in British Columbia, and he had answered that such a thing desirable and necessary. He found that the Indians were not so far advanced as those in the West, and he was particularly anxious that all throughout the Province they should receive a fair share of free education. He expressed the desire for education among Indians and asked the Government to give the initiative to the Government to give this matter its proper attention, and he looked for considerable progress in this direction in the near future.

You will note from the report of this Nurse that the Indian girls are not being taught to milk. This is a most serious situation and I think something should be done about it. What are we going to do when these women return to their reserves to live as farmers and are not able to milk cows? Are they to employ maids? The Department should insist on these girls being taught to milk cows at the school. One of our greatest difficulties is to get these people to keep milk cows so that their children and sick ones can have the necessary milk which is prescribed by the medical officers. Life in an Indian Residential School

Another Phase of Home Mission Work

By J. F. WOODSWORTH

(From "The New Outlook")

This year has been a very busy and a very interesting one. About eighty children came to us from Brandon during the period of their incarceration there, and also we are glad to report that we have had a total enrollment of nearly two hundred and fifteen pupils. This has of course been due to the enlargement of our quarters and considerable addition to our personnel, our usual attendance is only about half that number. These children come from all over Canada. We have now about twenty-five children from British Columbia. The Brandon children are from Lake Winnipeg and Ontario, representing a good many different tribes and languages. Our own Alberta children represent at least six different reserves, so that we have a great aggregation to mould into a harmonious working school. When the children came back from their holidays in August there were times of ecstatic times. Sometimes it was quite exciting. Sometimes there were tears; sometimes it was highly amusing. There was a great clash of loyalty and prejudices; however, after months of patient and conscientious work, we think we have a very fine group of children.

It may be of interest to let you know how we spent the Easter holidays. Perhaps you will get from it a good idea of activities just a little out of our ordinary routine. On Thursday night just before the class-room teachers went for holidays, we had a very interesting programme. The numbers were chiefly musical and rendered to the delight of everyone. The Indian people do not go to school. The next day was Good Friday. Of course our usual duties had to be looked after, but in the afternoon everybody had a holiday. The chief boys came back again with the boys of Rev. W. H. Pike's mission. These boys and our Indian boys are great friends and often have contests of various kinds. We played a long time, but our boys won. We had a very good Good Friday service in the evening when Dr. A. C. Farrell, of Wesley Church and Mr. Pike assisted me in instructions. Dr. Farrell preached a very fine and helpful sermon upon suitable theme. Our Sunday services were very impressive and were enjoyed by all. The Easter decorations and flowers were beautiful. I say nothing of the eager cooperation of over two hundred children who filled our chapel. I find my Indian congregation very inspiring and appreciative.
LIFE IN AN INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Another Phase of Home Mission Work

By J. F. Woodsworth.

(From "The New Outlook")

On Monday evening another treat was in store for us. We secured from the Extension Department of the University of Alberta four reels of moving pictures: two on the old story of "Sleepy Hollow" and two on life in India. The work was greatly entertained. To this we added a fine talk by Rev. Capt. Bob Pearson on some of his varied experiences. On Tuesday evening four of the pupils went to the city to assist in a Mission Band concert which was being put on at Norwood United Church. We finally finished our week of holidays with another one of our larger giving dinner party as guests at a C.G.I.T. affair at Central United Church in Edmonton.

I mention this week's program not to indicate our life in the residential school. The Indian people are taking their part in the life of the community and we are trying to fit them for community usefulness. Each day each girl and boy completes something in the way of school work. The girls in the various household departments, the boys about the farm. We are working five hundred acres this year. It is interesting to see the development of the life of a boy from the time he comes in from the reserve a child. Frequently his early days are spent in making mischief, but he usually makes up for it afterwards by becoming a real man and a fine worker before he leaves the school.

Our class-room work is progressing. Last year two girls took the Grade 8 or this year high school. One of them is now a nurse in training in the Royal Alexandra Hospital, Edmonton. The other is a helper at our Industrial School. This year we have two boys taking their Grade 9 and quite a good-sized entrance class. The Department of Indian Affairs is making a special grant to assist in this high school work. The difficulties of the residential schools are upon us, and every advance creates problems for the school. The methods of fifteen years ago are no longer suitable for our needs. We have met in this school grandfathers of former pupils. It is interesting to see the ex-pupils bring along their children. There is now none of the former hostility and suspicion. They know that the school is good for their children, not only from an educational standpoint, but from the health consideration. During this last year the Department has spent thousands of dollars on the treatment of these children. Tonics have been removed in about twenty-five cases. Under-nourished and children physically defective have been treated. Quite a number of persons in cases have been successfully handled, although we lost two little chaps who were not able to fight their way back to health again.

Our work here is essentially human in all its aspects and our greatest satisfaction is in seeing our pupils develop into good men and women who will take their places in the world.

This danger could be overcome by placing a landing platform at the second floor which would cut the length of the drop in half. I would recommend that this be done.

I am still of the opinion that a second well would be advisable and upon looking into the matter I find that the present pump house is large enough to take care of both wells and the outlay for the additional would be the cost of another pump and sinking the well.

This school is now connected up with the Calgary Power Company's system which supplies energy for lighting the school and running the laundry and pumping machinery.

There is a new bread mixer two barrel capacity on hand which the Principal has no use for and he will gladly turn it over to any other institution upon receiving advice to do so from the Department.

FARM

Water is piped from the pump house to the piggery and it will be an easy matter to connect the system to the cow barn. This system would be more efficient if a small pressure tank was installed in the pump house. A 500 gallon tank would fill the requirement.

Since my last visit a frame building has been moved from an outlying part of the farm and has been fitted up as a hog house the work being performed by the members of the staff. This building is dry, well ventilated and makes a good piggery. There are 20 brood sows and 175 other pigs on hand. The raising of hogs has proved a profitable source of income.

There are 60 heads of cattle on hand including a bull and 24 milch cows. They were milking 20 cows at the time of my visit which provides plenty of milk for their requirements.

The cow barn provides accommodation for the milch cows only and part of the horse barn is being used to house the other cattle. A shed is required for the young stock and the Principal stated that if he were granted $600.00 for the necessary material he could have a suitable shed built and would have the work done by the members of the staff.

The farm produced 16,200 bushels of grain, 100 tons of ensilage and sufficient hay and green feed for their feed requirements. The grain included 1200 bus wheat, 12,000 bus oats and 3000 bus barley.

The garden produced 3,000 bus of potatoes of good quality as well as enough turnips for their use but the carrots and other vegetables did not grow so well and they will not have sufficient to last them through the year.
General

There are 147 children in attendance, 71 boys and 76 girls. I visited both class rooms and noted that the pupils were clean, well clothed and had a healthy and well nourished appearance. They spend one half of the day at class and the other half at domestic and other work. The girls assist in the kitchen and in the general house work of the school. They are also given instruction in sewing, mending and knitting.

The boys assist with the feeding and care of the stock and in season they work on the farm.

In view of the healthy appearance of the children I was surprised that the cost for medical attendance has greatly increased since the appointment of Mr. Williamson and this is causing the Principal some anxiety. The account for October last was $208.50 for November $300.00 and for December $164.00.

Amongst the items noted are 13 tonsil treatments at $15.00 each. Five intravenous injections (five children syphilis) at $25.00. Four trips at $25.00 in one month. I also noted an $8.00 charge for a visit and the only work apparently performed was the examination of one child for admission to the school.

The Doctor is appointed on the call system but after being called he uses his own discretion regarding return visits. While the Principal feels that he is not qualified to say that these visits are not necessary he has a feeling that they might be curtailed. I am informed that the cost for medical attendance is three times as much as it was when Dr Holmes had the work.

In concluding this report I may state that I find the general conditions at this institution very satisfactory.

I visited this school on the 20th instant and made a complete inspection of the residence and outbuildings.

This school is under the auspices of the United Church with the Rev'd J.F.Woodsworth in charge as Principal; Miss McDonald Matron, Mr Goodlands in charge of the Farm and outside work also acts as assistant Principal when the Principal is absent on business trips. There are two qualified teachers as well as the necessary staff to carry on the work of the Institution all of whom have been selected with care and are reported as giving satisfactory service.

Mr Woodsworth impresses me as being an energetic and capable Principal. He keeps in close touch with all departments of the institution and I consider that his school reflects credit upon himself and the Department.

Main Building

This building has been fully described in former reports. I found the building in good condition throughout and well kept in a scrupulously clean manner.

I am writing you these few lines to inform you how I am getting along in this school. I am not getting along fine up here because I work all the time, and I don't go to school right. Sir:- Re - Edmonton Indian Residential School.

I am enclosing herewith a letter received from a Kitwancool pupil of this Agency, now at the Edmonton Residential School. The letter is self explanatory but I cannot say as to it being authentic.

To explain the situation more fully I had great difficulty in getting the pupils to return on September 1st last to the above school, the complaints chiefly being, from both parents and children - especially the boys - that they are continually working on the farm, thereby getting little or no education.

Dealing with the writer of the enclosed letter, Eddie Smith, this boy, who was a pupil of the above mentioned school and who was very anxious to learn, went to the Alert Bay School and positively refused to go to Edmonton. As this was contrary to Departmental orders the boy was returned to the Edmonton School on Departmental instructions from Ottawa.

I feel that if rumours of this description are circulated amongst the Protestant Indians it will have a bad effect and great difficulty will be experienced in getting the children to enter the said school.

May I be permitted to ask that if Inspector Barry is in the vicinity of the Alberta Border he proceed to Edmonton and check up all pupils of this Agency which, I am given to understand, are the only ones attending from B.C.

No doubt a part of the time should be devoted by the Indian boys to agriculture but a larger amount of time should be devoted to education.

Dear Sir;

I have your letter of 4th Inst. No. 110-0-1 in reference to complaints of parents and children from the Babine Agency.

I am rather glad of this letter as it gives me an opportunity to discuss matters which otherwise I might not mention. I wish I might talk rather than write, as there is nothing in these complaints as I see things and yet I know that these complaints exist and a certain amount of agitation goes on, which of course one cannot help. I have an idea also that the complaints come from, chiefly, one or two sources, and that from a family which did not send their children back to the school last August.

As far as work on the farm is concerned, the boys have been treated the same as our own Alberta boys, only better. For a few weeks during harvest some of the big boys were out getting the harvest in. The B.C. boys were put on the regular school schedule first, as I wished to prevent this very criticism. Practically all the B.C. boys were in from the harvest field by the end of September. As a matter of fact all the boys were rather anxious to have a hand in the harvest. But, the extra work done was no more than was necessary at a school farm. The Department is quite aware of the benefits of a school farm as a form of vocational training and I do not think I need apologize for having the boys do their share in getting in a harvest. I may say in passing that this year we had
one of the biggest crops, of all kinds, in the history of our school. We harvested 15,000 bus of grain, several thousand bus of vegetables of various kinds. A wonderful crop of green feed, and a fine herd of cattle to which to feed it, to say nothing to the finest herd of hogs in this part of the country. In the cases of many of these boys, I consider this farm education the best kind of training they could have, and many of our Alberta boys, and parents, appreciate this training, and ask to stay out of the class room. In the case of the B.C. boys however I have not allowed this except during the short time during harvest.

The whole trouble, of course, is that nearly every parent in B.C. asks that his boy or girl be allowed to go to school all day. They do not wish them to do any work on the farm. They want them suddenly to become fine scholars, after allowing them to run the streets of their villages until they are big boys and girls. There are a number of cases where these big boys are still in grade I and II. I cannot allow our Alberta children to do all the work and the B.C. children to sit down and look on. We cannot destroy our half day system. I know it is unpopular with them, but I am afraid I am forced to be unpopular at times with a certain class. Then too I fancy the village life on the Skeena has not been overly healthy. For the most part these big boys have wandered the streets since children and of course resent the first indication of discipline or restraint. Practically all are in Grade I when they come here, and have no idea at all of school life. Naturally some will complain to parents.

It may only be a coincident, but the two B.C. young people who from the first have gone to school all day and upon whom we have expended the most care are the two who have been sick most. Again there are about 35 children who are in the class room both morning and afternoon. Of these 15 are from B.C. Yet we have twice as many children
from Alberta as from B.C., I might also point out that those B.C. children who have kept in school regularly have made splendid progress with their studies. As far as work is concerned, we cannot depend upon the B.C. boys for any real duties. It is always the Alberta fellows. The last two mornings we have gone off for ice, an all day drive. Three Alberta Boys, and without a complaint. If the Department wishes to do real work among these young people I know of nothing which will do it like our present policy. As I understand it we are here to guide these children educationally, and not allow our parental interference as long as justice is done. I am not ashamed of our graduates, but we cannot do this work by allowing children to have everything their own way.

About fighting:- This is nonsense. I have found that the B.C. boys are just like other boys and have their tiffs like other boys do. In cases of bullying I have punished the offenders severely. Sometimes one must act with decision. John Brown a B.C. boy attacks Sam Bird with a pitch fork. John of course is jacked up. Sometimes it is fit for tat. Joshua-I6-Alberta takes a swipe at Mike/I2-B.C. John-I6-P.C., in revenge kicks the shins of Norman/I8-Alberta. This is about as serious as our little tragedies amount to.

About food:- I went to the dining room this morning. I found at each plate-I4S children, a good bowl rolled oats porridge, a big cup of milk, three or four slices of bread or toast. Potatoes, Jam, and meat, and tea or cocoa. True it is served on a granite plate, but it was real food. The two Steinhauer children who have a ten mile drive to Alberta College where they are taking Grades Ten and Twelve sit at the same table as these children and there is never complaint. One B.C. boy informed me that he wanted Bacon and eggs for breakfast. However I concluded that I was not serving a menu A'La Hotel MacDonald. There is
too much the attitude that the Government owes us everything and we should get it. I fancy food is about the same in Alberta as in B.C., and our meals are open to Government inspection, and have been approved by Visiting nurses. If fish were more plentiful we might give them some more frequently, but as it is we have it in season.

Probably I have written enough. I trust you will write Mr. Indian Agent Mortimer, if you are satisfied that this school is giving the children fair treatment, so that he may definitely inform the Indian People of the Babine Agency that the children are receiving their education, not merely according to the plan of a particular Principal but also after a policy which has the full backing of The Department. There were seven or eight children who did not come back last August when I went for them. It is possible that The Indian Agent did not care to enforce their return for various reasons. I think they should have come back, as their absence was a mere whim of their parents. They were registered in this school and considerable expense was involved in getting them here.

I have considerable stake in B.C. I believe we can give these children a good training for a few years and prepare them for future educational developments later in B.C. I would appreciate very much the backing of the Department and also the local Indian Agent in this task.

I shall be glad if the Department enquires further into our educational work and our treatment of the children here. Any information is welcomed. I shall be glad to hear further from the Department upon matters relative to the B.C. situation.

Yours Truly,

J.G. Woodworth
Principal

I respectfully beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of February 16th, No. 110-0-1, with enclosure from the Rev. J. N. Woodsworth, Principal of the above named Residential School.

After carefully perusing Mr. Woodsworth's letter and from past investigations of the reports which I have received concerning the pupils of this Agency, I am of opinion that the treatment meted out to these pupils are in accordance with the syllabus carried through by Mr. Woodsworth and appear to be satisfactory. I have no hesitation in saying that most of the complaints submitted to me by the parents emanated from the children themselves and no doubt were greatly enlarged upon by the parents with a view of trying to get an Indian Residential School built in this Agency. I had the same complaints from the parents of children attending the Fraser Lake Indian Residential School at Leduc, B. C. These complaints raised a doubt in my mind until I personally visited the Fraser Lake School and found the complaints were a series of untruths. I have great pleasure in stating that I have met Mr. Woodsworth and have heard from him regarding his procedure of tuition in both the class room and on the farm and I am fully convinced that Mr. Woodsworth and his staff are doing their best to educate Indian children so that in the future they will become an asset to Canada. Mr. Woodsworth may rest assured that he will receive every assistance from this Agency.

Dealing with the matter of Indian children of this Agency whose parents refuse to return them to Edmonton, I may say that these parents are well able to look after their children locally and send them to the Indian Day Schools. This, I think, meets with the wishes of the Department.

In conclusion may I be permitted to say that I am of opinion that the holiday season should be curtailed as far as possible when one takes into consideration the long train journey and expensive transportation between Hazleton and Edmonton.

I return herewith Mr. Woodsworth's letter as requested.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of the Edmonton Indian Residential School. My inspection covered a period of about 30 hours which I spent at this institution.

There are 158 children in residence: 81 girls and 77 boys. The government grant provides for 150 children, or 8 less than they have in attendance. The children in residence there are from the Edmonton, Saddle Lake and Hobema Agencies, and there are something like 60 from British Columbia Reserves.

There are two classrooms in the school. During my time there I spent considerable time in both of these, and I found that excellent work was being carried on. The grades taught are from I to VIII. Both teachers are well qualified and getting good results. Three graduates from the school are attending high school in Edmonton: They drive into the city every morning and come out at night. I will not dwell on the classroom work here, as the school was inspected last November by the Provincial Public School Inspector.

FARMING:

The school has 855 acres of land all fenced. They have 550 acres of this land under

Dr. Harold W. McGill,

Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,

OTTAWA.
Farming (Continued),—

cultivation. The crop harvested this year was 2500 bushels of wheat, 9000 bushels of oats and 3000 bushels of barley—a total of 14,500 bushels of grain. Besides this they had 3000 bushels of potatoes and an abundance of all other varieties of vegetables and garden truck. One hundred and fifty (150) tons of green feed were raised and placed in the silo.

During the summer I called at the school on two different occasions and saw the farming, gardens, &c., and all outside work was well performed.

LIVE STOCK:

They have 15 horses and 59 head of cattle, of which 29 are cows. At the time of my visit they were milking 24 head. They have also 135 pigs, 50 chickens and 25 turkeys.

The milk cows at the school are probably the finest herd in Alberta, as quite a number of them came from the C. P. R. Farm at Strathmore. The cattle and horses are very well looked after; the same applies to the pigs: Mr. Woodsworth has made a real business of raising hogs. He sells quite a number each year and they are all sold as "selects."

BUILDINGS, &c.,

The buildings throughout are in very good shape and the same applies to machinery, furniture and equipment of all kinds.

Training outside of Classroom Work:

The girls get about the same training as at all other boarding schools in the way of cooking, housekeeping, sewing, &c.

The boys here get exceptionally good training in farming and stock raising. From the results of their farming operations you may judge that the farming is well performed.
HEALTH:
The children at this school looked very well. The school is in good financial condition, and as they raise practically all their food requirement the children get all they can eat. For instance, all the older boys and girls get meat and potatoes three times a day, and the children get butter at practically every meal. The wheat is ground into flour, and all the pork and beef used at the school is slaughtered right there.

GENERAL:
The management of the school is exceptionally good. Mr. Goodland the Farming Instructor, has been there for 10 years. Before that he had been at Brandon for 20 years. He now has an assistant and they are accomplishing a great deal.

Miss MacDonald the Matron has been in the work for 21 years, first at the File Hills School, then at Birtle and then she came to the Edmonton School shortly after it was opened. She is very capable and is doing splendid work.

Rev. Mr. Woodswroth, the Principal, is certainly to be congratulated on the splendid institution he is running. He has the work well organized and the children have every opportunity of being fitted for the live in which they will be engaged. All work done by the children both outside and in, is done well. The only thing I regret is, that the school should be filled up with children from the three nearby Agencies instead of having children there from B.C. Agencies. In due course I hope this situation will rectify itself, but it was necessary to bring the
GENERAL (Continued),-

British Columbia Indian children in order to bring the school up to capacity.

This is the first time I have inspected this school, as during the time I was in Regina, I did not inspect anything North of Edmonton.

I trust this report will be of interest to you.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,

Inspector of Indian Agencies,

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of the Edmonton Indian Residential School, which I did on my way back from Fort Chipewyan, when I stopped off in Edmonton for a couple of days. At the time of my visit there were 143 children in residence, 67 boys and 76 girls.

SCHOOL AND OUTBUILDINGS:

The school building itself is in splendid condition as the staff keep it in good repair. A small amount of money has been authorized by the Department each year for paint and calsonine, &c., and the walls were bright and clean; in fact the whole building looked very well kept.

The outbuildings were also in good order: Of course there is always a certain amount of depreciation in buildings from year to year: breakages and things going out of order, but everything seemed to be kept in a fairly good state of repair. I noticed that the brick work on the pump-house had given way, but had been temporarily repaired by the school, which answers the purpose. I also noticed that the silo was in

Doctor Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
School & Outbuildings, (Continued),—

very poor condition; Many of the staves have rotted and given way. The silo had been fixed up by putting 2 X 4's vertically on the walls, and then putting steel rods around as hoops to tighten the silo up, and prevent it from leaking. This will keep it in shape for two or three years, at least. The rest of the outbuildings were in a good state of repair, and as far as I could see, everything that needed repairing had been attended to by the School.

I went through the three residences at the school and found these to be in good shape. The furniture in the school was in good order.

The farm machinery at the school is kept under cover, and everything in this line seemed to be in good repair. The boiler in the school, as well as the laundry machinery, &c., seemed to be in good working order.

FARMING:—

The school owns approximately 855 acres of land, all fenced, 550 acres of which is under cultivation, including gardens and the school grounds. The Principal informed me that he had leased between 275 and 300 acres of the cultivated land on shares to two neighbouring farmers. The farmers in question are Wm. Davidson and Alfred Latimer, and the arrangements between them and the school are on the usual crop-share basis. The school
Farming, (Continued),—

Authorities reserve the right to determine what land is to be farmed and summer-fallowed each year, and the threshing machine belonging to the school is to be used in threshing the crop. Mr. Woodsworth also reserves the right to purchase green feed or any grain he requires for the school from the farmers who are working the land. The reason given me for entering into this agreement with the outside farmers was that all of the older boys had been discharged from the school and they did not have the staff to handle the land in question. The balance of the land under cultivation was handled by the school staff and boys. The farm work at this institution is carried on in a very satisfactory manner and the work on the land is always well performed, as I have seen the summer-fallows several times during the summer.

The amount of grain received from their farming operations last fall was 1300 bushels of wheat, 5000 bushels of oats and 600 bushels of barley, and 50 tons of green feed; as well as 3000 bushels of potatoes and an abundance of all other garden truck. I went through the root cellar which is an excellent one, and noted that the school had a good supply of potatoes, beets, turnips, carrots, parsnips and onions, from which it will be seen that they maintain a good garden. It might be interesting to you to note that the receipts from their farming operations in the past year amounted to about $3500.00
LIVE STOCK:

They have 60 head of cattle, 35 of which are milch cows, and at the time of my visit they were milking 24. The cattle are mostly Holsteins but a few Shorthorn cows are kept as well for the purpose of breeding Beef animals for the use of the school. They have 150 pigs of different ages and size, and approximately 160 have been disposed of during the year. These hogs are of the very finest bacon type, and I noted from the sales slips that most of them had been graded "select." There are 13 head of work horses of a good type. They have also about 100 chickens.

I went over the records as to the amount of milk that came into the school and there is certainly an abundance of milk produced for all the requirements of the children. Considerable butter is also made, which is used by the staff and the children.

TRAINING OF CHILDREN:

The children at this institution receive an exceptionally good training, as very nearly everything in the way of food, &c., is produced right there. The wheat raised is ground into flour which is used at the school, and the bigger girls bake the bread; No bread is purchased. Then, of course, the girls are taught the usual household work including, sewing, &c. The boys help to look after the barns and stock and receive a certain amount of training in the repair shop both in carpentering and blacksmithing, repairing implements, &c.
HEALTH:

The children appeared happy and well. Two of the girls were ill with colds at the time of my visit, but otherwise there seemed to be no sickness at the school.

I visited the children's dining room for the noon-day and evening meals, and from my own observation I would say that the children receive good food, well put up, and are getting all they can eat.

For recreation during the winter time they have a skating rink and I noticed that both girls and boys had been furnished with skates and boots, and they certainly make good use of them. In the summer time they play baseball, football, &c.

GENERAL:

I was in both classrooms and good work was evidently being carried on. This school maintains the services of two competent teachers.

From remarks that have been dropped by officials from Ottawa, who have visited here, I believe that some of them are under the impression that the children are overworked at this institution: The older boys, in years gone by, probably did a lot of work on the farm, but at times they were paid by Mr. Woodsworth for staying on during the holidays and doing the farming, and one of the reasons for him leasing the land he did was to divert any criticism along those lines. On
General, (Continued),—

this occasion I enquired into this matter very thoroughly and found that the ice put up at the school was hauled in and packed by outsiders.

I also found that the coal burned at the school was delivered by truck right into the coal shed and basement, and therefore the boys had none of this work to do. As far as I could ascertain neither boys or girls were being overworked.

The personnel of the staff at an institution of this kind has a great deal to do with the treatment of the children. I have known the Matron, Miss McDonald, for years, in fact ever since I first came into the Department, and anyone who knows her can recognize her sterling qualities: She is efficient in her work and at the same time kind and generous to the children, and she certainly has their interest at heart.

Mr. Goodland, the senior Farming Instructor is an excellent type of man; He has been in the employ of the Department for over 30 years and his work is always well performed; I am quite sure that boys working under a man of his type are treated with every consideration.

The whole staff of the school appeared to me to be very efficient: There are six male members of the staff including the reverend Principal, 2 Farming Instructors, an engineer, a teacher and a boys' superintendent; and 8 female members — 14 in all. I had quite a conversation with the engineer who looks after all the machinery around the school,— the boilers, &c., and from my personal observation I would say that he is well qualified
General, (Continued),—

to look after the machinery.

Mr. Woodsworth, the reverend Principal, is well known to the Department. He is an excellent business man and runs an up-to-date institution and the school is self-supporting in every respect. In the matter of them having the school land worked on shares, I am of the opinion that this should have been taken up with the Department beforehand, but as I did not know where I stood in the matter, I did not say anything.

I trust this report will be of interest to you.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,

Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.

Reverend Sir,

For some years past, children from British Columbia, especially from the Babine Agency, have been placed in the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

Although the Department frequently received protests regarding such action, it was considered advisable to give the matter a fair trial. We have now reached the decision that it is undesirable to place any more British Columbia children in the Edmonton Indian Residential School.

The letter which you recently forwarded in connection with holidays indicates that, for the next school year, there will not be more than seventeen (17) British Columbia children in the Edmonton School. All of these should be discharged as soon as they reach the age limit prescribed by the Indian Act unless there are some very special circumstances. Each of the latter will have to be dealt with on its own merits.

A copy of this letter is being forwarded to Acting Indian Agent Mallinson, Hazelton, B. C.

I may say that I am very unhappy with regard to the lack of progress made by the Indian pupils going to the Residential School near Edmonton. I am told that the B.C. Indians are quite out of touch with various activities there as they are not considered by the Indians on the Alberta side of the Rocky Mountains as of the same stock. If children must be sent to a Residential School, I certainly consider that Alert Bay would be the most suitable. The Indian parents are complaining of the long distance to Edmonton, and the fact that they do not see their children in some cases for years. The whole system of instruction at Edmonton appears to be different to that followed in British Columbia, and I would ask you to support my recommendation if you can see your way to do so.

I am quite aware that the distance is too great for most cases and also that the friction occasioned by protests of parents to this school, the Agency at Hazelton and its reaction on Ottawa is not calculated to once peace of mind. However I would like to add that as far as the purpose of this school is concerned, namely that of educating the child, I think we have maintained our standards. Of the group about to leave, two are in high school, three in Grade VIII, and others in the higher public school grades. We have also done our best along vocational lines. It is nine years since we first brought children from the Babine Agency. Nearly one hundred children have been recruited from that district for this school during the nine years. According to this summary I am asking for the definite discharge of thirteen pupils. The retention of 13 boys plus 7 girls under 16 years, and also the three special cases above named; namely, Jeffrey Fowler, Annie McDames, and Emma Simpson.
It will be noted that an analysis of the B.C. children here works out somewhat differently from my first letter which was not intended to be a definite recommendation, particularly in view of your two recent letters which have closed B.C. to further recruiting.

If the Department insists upon further discharges I would like to make recommendations as there are some whom I would rather see go than others.

If The Department would allow holidays for the following children with the understanding that they be allowed to return to this school again this fall I would like to have them go for just a holiday. Emma Simpson, Jim Fowler, Tommy Danae, Philip Crosby, and perhaps Willis Morgan. From The Departments letters it is evidently not the intention to immediately close out the entire B.C. group until they reach the age limit.

In regard to travelling expenses. It cost me $140.40 to send the nine boys to Hazelton yesterday morning. $15.60 each. The six girls next Wed will cost $95.80. The other five mentioned for holidays will cost $46.80.

If The Department could get a telegram to me by next Tuesday with instructions I could get any who are to go off by bed morning. I would also like to know if the Department approves of the general plan as outlined in this letter. I quite realise that there will be a number of exceptions.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September, and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter."

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter."

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return, the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.
